headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Tiffany & Co. Fourth Quarter Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Participating on today's call is Mr. Mark Aaron, Vice President of Investor Relations; and Michael Kowalski, Chairman of the Board and int
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Tiffany & Co. Fourth Quarter Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Participating on today's call is Mr. Mark Aaron, Vice President of Investor Relations; and Michael Kowalski, Chairman of the Board and interim Chief Executive Officer; and Mr. Mark Erceg, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mr. Mark Aaron. Please go ahead.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year 2016 conference call. I'm delighted that Tiffany's Chairman of the Board and interim CEO, Mike Kowalski; and our CFO, Mark Erceg, are on today's call. We'll review actua
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year 2016 conference call. I'm delighted that Tiffany's Chairman of the Board and interim CEO, Mike Kowalski; and our CFO, Mark Erceg, are on today's call. We'll review actual results and comments on the 2017 outlook and then we'll allow time to answer some questions. 
Before proceeding, please note that statements made on this call that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. Actual results might differ materially from the planned, assumed or expected results expressed in or implied by these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors, risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially is set forth in Tiffany's Form 10-K, 10-Q and 8-K reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission including the news release filed today under cover of Form 8-K. The company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement to reflect subsequent events or circumstances, except as required by applicable law or regulation. 
Okay. By now, I hope you've had a chance to read today's news release, which indicated fourth quarter and full year results that were in line with the guidance that we provided in January and reaffirmed last month. Worldwide net sales rose slightly in the fourth quarter and earnings per diluted share declined slightly. For the full year, worldwide net sales declined 3%, diluted EPS declined 1% on a GAAP basis and 2% when excluding charges in both years, and we managed our balance sheet effectively generating strong cash flow in the year. 
So let's review the results starting with the top line. First, there were no meaningful changes in regional sales mix in 2016, with the Americas representing 46% of worldwide sales, Asia-Pacific at 25%, Japan at 15% and Europe at 11%. In the Americas, total sales and comparable store sales declined in both the fourth quarter of the year as a result of lower jewelry units sold. In the U.S., we experienced softness across most of the countries for the year although at lesser rates in some stores as the year progressed. In addition to the full year, sales weakness in Canada was partly offset by growth in Latin America. We attributed a portion of the softness in the U.S. throughout the year to local customers which we believe was tied to macro, market and political uncertainties. Sales attributed to foreign visitors decline in the full year which we attribute to lower spending by Chinese visitors, but we believe total sales benefited in the second half of the year due to increased spending by Japanese tourists. We estimate that U.S. sales in 2016 to foreign tourists remained at approximately 20%. 
We've previously spoken about the impact of postelection activities near our New York flagship store, which represents less than 10% of worldwide sales. While we typically do not discuss individual store results, we are, for at least this quarter, reporting its sales results because of the unique situation and level of investor interest. Sales in the New York flagship declined 11% in the full year and 7% in the entire fourth quarter versus the 14% decline in the November, December holiday period due to some large transactions in January. In addition, we estimate spending by foreign tourists in that store remained at roughly 40% of its annual sales. 
Elsewhere during 2016, we opened one store in Canada in the department store in Toronto, relocated our store in Vancouver and relocated our store in King of Prussia mall outside Philadelphia. Of course, we also continued to renovate many stores, highlighted by magnificent upgrades to our stores in Beverly Hills and San Francisco. 
Turning to Asia-Pacific. While total sales were roughly unchanged in the year, we were pleased to see a healthy rate of growth in the second half and fourth quarter that was generated by increases in jewelry units sold. During the year, we were very pleased with strong total and comparable store sales growth in Mainland China as we believe the Tiffany & Co. brand continues to gain recognition and prominence with customers. I should add that lower spending that we attributed to Chinese tourists in other regions in 2016 may have led to some of the higher spending that we saw by local consumers within China. 
Also in the Greater China market, we were pleased to see smaller sequential sales declines in Hong Kong as the year progressed. However, there was noteworthy softness in much of the year in Australia and Taiwan. 
We significantly enhanced our store presence in Asia-Pacific in 2016. We opened 7 stores, relocated 2 and closed 3. In China, we opened 3 stores in Ningbo Heyi, in Tianjin Hisense and in, and we closed 2 stores, one in Beijing in the Peninsula Hotel and one at the Tianjin Friendship store. We finished the year with 31 stores in Mainland China. 
In addition, we opened our 15th store in Korea in the Shinsegae Hanam department store. We opened our first store in New Zealand in Auckland's magnificent Britomart precinct. And we opened 2 stores in Australia, one in the Gold Coast Pacific Fair and one in the Sydney airport. In Singapore, we relocated our store at Changi Airport and closed our store in Raffles Hotel. 
In Japan, we achieved healthy retail sales growth in 2016 even excluding the favorable translation benefit from the stronger yen and finished the year on a strong note. We were pleased to have an increased in jewelry units sold in the fourth quarter and full year in Japan that span most categories. Anecdotally, we believe our already strong presence in Japan further benefited from the brand exposure we received on a popular television show called For The Romantic which aired in the July-September time frame. In addition, we believe that the stronger yen has been a factor contributing to the increased purchasing attributed to Japanese tourists that we've experienced in other regions. Conversely, that stronger yen has likely been the reason for less tourist spending in Japan, primarily attributed to Chinese visitors, would converse the trend we saw in 2015. However, we believe our sales in Japan are made largely by Japanese customers and we continue to estimate that spending by foreign tourists represented less than 10% of sales in Japan. Lastly in Japan, we had a net reduction of 1 store in 2016 as we closed the store in the Takashimaya department store, while we relocated 2 stores during the year in Nagoya and Kagoshima. 
Conversely, it was a challenging year in Europe. Total sales declined on a reported basis in the fourth quarter and full year, primarily reflecting weakening European currencies. On a constant exchange rate basis, total sales declined to a lesser extent in the year and actually rose slightly in the fourth quarter. The sales weakness arose largely from lower jewelry unit volume across all categories. Throughout the year, we experienced varying degrees of soft demands, partly attributed to local customers that we believe is the result of economic and political conditions and also attributed to lower spending by foreign tourists likely tied to the effects of the tragic events in Paris and elsewhere. We estimate that spending attributed to foreign tourists generally represents in the neighborhood of 1/4 to 1/3 of total European sales. In both the fourth quarter and the full year, results were soft across much of Continental Europe, while sales on a constant exchange rate basis in the U.K., which represents roughly 40% of European sales -- sales rose in the U.K. which represents about 40% of European sales. In fact, we believe the sales lift that we saw in the U.K. in the second half of the year was from spending attributed to foreign tourists after the British pound declined following the Brexit vote. We opened 3 stores in Europe in 2016 including 2 in Italy on Rome's Condotti and in Venice and a second store in Amsterdam in the BM Court department store, and we closed a small store at the Frankfurt airport. 
I commented several times on the significant spending attributed to foreign tourists in most regions. In general, tourism flows up from one region to another may be affected by changes in currency values as well as geopolitical and other external factors. Therefore, we believe that creating and reinforcing local and global brand recognition is most relevant to growing our business regardless of where the spending might occur in the short term. Lastly, lower sales in our other segment in both fourth quarter and full year resulted from comp store sales declines in our 5 stores in the United Arab Emirates. Also sales increased in the full year but were roughly unchanged in the fourth quarter. In terms of store productivity, worldwide gross sales per gross square foot for company-operated stores was $2,700 in 2016 compared with $2,900 in 2015, resulting from the 3% increase in worldwide gross square footage and the modest worldwide sales decline. By region, sales productivity in 2016 ranged from $3,800 in Asia-Pacific to $3,700 in Japan to $2,500 in Europe and to $2,200 in the Americas. Keep in mind that these productivity levels are calculated in US dollars, and therefore, year-to-year differences also reflect foreign currency changes. 
Our strategies partly revolve Art Deco optimizing our worldwide store base through openings, relocations and renovations and closings. We expect this to result in an increase in global square footage by approximately 2% a year for the foreseeable future. This initiative goes hand in hand with our strategy to more proactively reach customers to deliver more engaging shopping experience, to deepen long-term relationships with customers and, ultimately, to increase the frequency of store visits and conversion rates. 
Beyond the Tiffany & Co. stores we operate in 28 countries, we also serve customers through e-commerce-enabled websites in 13 of those countries. Worldwide e-commerce sales were approximately unchanged in the year and continued to represent 6% of Tiffany's worldwide sales but were a somewhat higher percentage in the U.S. alone. As we've said many times, our website serves an important dual function of generating online sales but also delivering marketing communication that drives awareness and store traffic. That covers regional sales results. 
Looking at the product side, from a sales perspective, trends indicated general softness across all jewelry categories to varying degrees. Despite that, there were some noteworthy product-related highlights in 2016. During the year, we introduced some new designs, refreshed some existing collections and, importantly, have said that we intend to accelerate the pace of newness going forward. The relative improvements that we've seen in fashion jewelry sales can be attributed to higher gold jewelry sales, exemplified by the T Collection which we have continued to build upon with new designs. We also saw relative improvement in fashion silver jewelry in 2016, led by the popularity of the new Return to Tiffany Love collection with silver jewelry sales approaching stabilization after years of decline. We focused on product newness in silver jewelry in 2016 and grew the number of new items under $500 by more than 10%. 
I should also mention success in our designer jewelry category which we are now disclosing on its own, driven by Elsa Peretti's jewelry collections highlighted in 2016 by her exquisite Diamonds by the Yard and the open heart designs and the designs of Paloma Picasso, highlighted by her popular Olive Leaf and her new Paloma's Melody collection. 
Engagement jewelry and wedding bands category posted mixed sales performance by region during the year, although we were pleased to see unit volume growth in the quarter and the full year on a worldwide basis. Relatively speaking, the softness product category was high fine and solitaire jewelry. We continue to be pleased with the success of our Victoria collections in platinum and diamonds. However, there was some softness at the highest end of this category. We had held our Blue Book event this spring attended by a global audience as we do every year, and the results, while strong, did not measure up to the huge success of those events in the prior 2 years. You should note that the term high jewelry now replaces the former term, statement jewelry. 
Lastly, I'll just mention that we continue to see healthy sales growth in the watch category in 2016. While watch sales have grown, albeit off at a low single-digit percentage of sales base, we see considerable opportunity over the longer term to expand that business through a combination of product development and marketing communication. 
That covers the top line review. I'm now pleased to turn the call over to Mark Erceg.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and welcome, everyone. Let me start by stating that while fourth quarter and full year GAAP and adjusted diluted earnings per share both were in line with our expectations, Tiffany's financial performance over the past couple of years has be
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and welcome, everyone. Let me start by stating that while fourth quarter and full year GAAP and adjusted diluted earnings per share both were in line with our expectations, Tiffany's financial performance over the past couple of years has been disappointing which is why I'm so pleased to be working with Mike Kowalski, the board and all Tiffany's dedicated and talented employees to accelerate the execution of our key strategies in the years ahead. 
One of those strategies is expanding our e-commerce and omnichannel capabilities which require us to upgrade certain IT systems. So I want to briefly comment on the $25.4 million impairment of capitalized software development costs we recognized in the fourth quarter of 2016. Simply put, as part of the comprehensive system review, we identified a solution which negated the need to install a separate inventory management and merchandising system which work had already begun on. By further leveraging our existing ERP system and in order management system we were in the process of implementing, we expect to be able to access the full range of capabilities we originally seeking but at a lower cost. This project, now that it has been recast, along with the rapid investments we are making information systems, will we believe make our supply chain more efficient, improve the customers' in-store experience and generate incremental sales by expanding and leveraging both our CRM and omnichannel capabilities. 
Let's now look at the rest of income statement. Gross margin for the fourth quarter was 64.1% which was up 110 basis points versus a year ago. In fact, gross margin increased year-over-year in every quarter as we benefited from favorable product input costs, 2015 pricing actions which carried over into 2016 and a favorable shift in product sales mix. For the full year, gross margin was 62.2% versus 60.7% last year, but unfortunately, the 150 basis points of gross margin expansion generated during 2016 was more than offset by increases in SG&A expense. SG&A expense as a percent of sales for the fourth quarter was 43.2%, up 170 basis points versus a year ago, and for the year, it was 44.2% which was up 200 basis points. The increases in SG&A expense as a percent of sales reflected sales deleveraging due to higher store occupancy and depreciation costs as well as higher labor and incentive compensation costs. Lowering the rate of SG&A expense growth as a percent of sales remains a top priority for the company going forward. 
Marketing spending as a percent of sales was roughly unchanged from the prior year. We continue to broaden Tiffany's presence in a variety of media and, as an example, appeared on television in February for our first Super Bowl commercial. The 62nd ad, which ran 10 key markets, featured Lady Gaga in order to set the stage for our new hardware jewelry collection which is launching next month. 
Net interest and other expenses in the fourth quarter and for the full year were below prior year due to both reduced foreign currency transactional losses and lower interest expense. Tiffany's full year effective tax rate was 34.1% which was down from last year's rate of 34.7% due to the favorable impact from the conclusion of a tax examination in the first quarter. 
Turning to the balance sheet and statement of cash flow. We finished the year with reasonable debt levels and generated strong cash flow, both of which gives us the ability to continue investing in our business while also returning excess cash to shareholders. Inventory finished the year 3% below a year ago at $2.2 billion. Accounts receivable at January 31 were 10% higher than the previous year-end with the increase partly tied to the timing of collections driven by sales growth in Japan since the majority of our stores' net market are operated within department stores. A portion of the increase was also currency-related. 
Capital expenditures for the year came in at $223 million with more than half of the spending related to the opening, renovation and/or relocation of stores. CapEx represented approximately 6% of worldwide sales during both 2016 and 2015. It's also worth pointing out that we made an unplanned and voluntary contribution of $120 million to Tiffany's U.S. pension plan during the fourth quarter of 2016. We expect this to lower our 2017 pension expense as a result of incremental returns expected to be generated on the investments made with that contribution and lower premiums owed to the PBGC. Putting it all together we generated $702 million of operating cash flow and $479 million of free cash flow in 2016 after giving effect to the $120 million voluntary pension contribution. Importantly, this was well above our initial goal of generating at least $400 of free cash flow for the year. In terms of share repurchases, we spent $184 million and bought more than 2 million shares in 2016. 
Turning to dividends. We increased the quarterly dividend by 12.5% in May which marked the 15th dividend increase in the past 14 years. We finished fiscal 2016 with $986 million of cash and short-term investments versus $1.1 billion of short-term and long-term debt, so total debt representing just 37% of stockholders' equity which was unchanged from the prior year. Tiffany's return on assets was 9% and return on stockholders' equity was 15%, both of which are generally consistent with our long-term objectives which call for a return of assets of at least 10% and a return on equity of at least 15%. 
Looking into 2017, our financial expectations recognize 2 import external challenges. First, we remain mindful of economic and geopolitical uncertainties and their potential effects on both local and foreign tourist spending. Second, since over half our sales continue to be outside the United States and we expect the U.S. dollar to be stronger on average than the prior year, we should be facing a sizable headwind in terms of translating our non-U.S. sales into dollars. In addition, we'll have to overcome the negative effect of stronger dollar they have on foreign tourists spending in the United States. Of course, we do openly acknowledge that we will partly benefit from the translation effect of non-U.S. expenses into dollars, but that positive impact is expected to be relatively minor compared to the 2 foreign exchange headwinds I just mentioned. We plan to open 11 stores in 2017, half in Asia-Pacific, relocate 9 and close, 6 representing a net 3% increase in global square footage. As part of our strategy to optimize the global store base, we will also continue to renovate some over existing stores. With this in mind, we expect total sales to increase by a low single-digit percentage over the prior year which, importantly, translates into a mid-single-digit increase over the prior year on a constant exchange rate basis. 
Moving further into the P&L. Our 2017 outlook assumes an increase in operating margin entirely due to an increase in gross margin, with SG&A expense growth just slightly higher than sales growth. The assumption of a higher gross margin is tied to favorable product input costs and proactive expense management. In addition, after not taking any meaningful price increases in 2016, except for currency changes, we took modest price increases in the past month that vary by country but average out to a low single-digit increase on a worldwide basis. Our 2017 outlook further assumes interest and other expense in of approximately $40 million, an effective tax rate consistent with the prior year and that we continue buying shares under our existing share repurchase program, although we expect minimal benefit to diluted earnings per share from the currently planned repurchases. 
Taking all this into account, our outlook falls for net earnings per diluted share to increase by a high single-digit percentage from last year's $3.55 per share on a GAAP basis and to increase by a mid-single-digit percentage over the adjusted $3.75 per share last year. We also plan to manage the balance sheet efficiently with a particular focus on not growing net inventories in order to generate net cash from operating activities of approximately $700 million and free cash flow of approximately $450 million for the full year. The difference of $250 million represents our plans on capital expenditures. 
I'm now pleased to turn the call over to Mike Kowalski for some brief comments before we open the call to your questions.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, gentlemen, for providing everyone with a thorough understanding of Tiffany's performance in 2016. I just want to address a few matters and then we'll be happy to take your questions. First, we began an external search in early February to fill
componenttext:
Thank you, gentlemen, for providing everyone with a thorough understanding of Tiffany's performance in 2016. I just want to address a few matters and then we'll be happy to take your questions. First, we began an external search in early February to fill the role of Chief Executive Officer when Frederic Cumenal stepped down from that position and I agreed to become interim CEO. We assumed that it may take time to find the right person with broad experience and brand management with a global perspective and who possess the strong leadership skills to motivate and inspire our Tiffany colleagues around the world. 
Second, although Tiffany in the luxury industry faced numerous macro challenges in 2016, we have not been pleased with our financial performance. While we were able to realize important improvement in gross margin and generate a healthy level of free cash flow, sales results were disappointing and we were unable to generate sales leverage on our fixed costs. 
Third, and most importantly, we believe that Tiffany has a set of powerful strategies that can propel our business forward in the long term. With the right leadership and pace of execution, we believe there are substantial opportunities to grow our business. Specifically, we are focused on increasing the rate of new product introductions and innovations and we recently announced the hiring of Reed Krakoff to serve as Chief Artistic Officer. We're also focused on maximizing our marketing effectiveness and building stronger relationships with customers, optimizing our store network and improving our business operations and processes all while effectively managing our capital and costs. And we remain absolutely committed to our industry-leading effort through our corporate social responsibility and environmental sustainability, an area of great importance and relevance to us and, we believe, to our customers as well. In essence, we are committed to executing with excellence the strategies that are within our control and pursuing long-term growth opportunities. 
This May 5, we'll mark the 30th anniversary of Tiffany's initial public offering in 1987. Since then, our company has generally produced strong returns for shareholders, and we intend to pursue opportunities that can continue to generate attractive total shareholder returns in the future. 
In my role as interim CEO, I have been actively engaged with the management teams and employees across our business, and I have no doubt that my colleagues at all levels share an extraordinary sense of dedication and passion for our company. I truly appreciate their efforts. And to all of you on this call, I appreciate your ongoing interest in Tiffany's progress. And now we'd be happy to answer some of your questions.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Omar Saad with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Omar Saad with Evercore ISI.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Warren on for Omar, I just had a question on accelerating the pace of newness. At the Investor Day last year, you discussed some ways that you're speeding up the process to use both product design and also the supply chain and bringing product to
componenttext: This is Warren on for Omar, I just had a question on accelerating the pace of newness. At the Investor Day last year, you discussed some ways that you're speeding up the process to use both product design and also the supply chain and bringing product to market more quickly. What parts of the assortment are turning faster than they were a year ago? And what's changed in terms of your structural capabilities to deliver on frequency and freshness?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly -- this is Mike, certainly, the portion of the product assortment in which we delivered new -- greater newness at a greater piece is in fashion product. And I think we've seen the sales results to the extent that fashion has grown faster,
componenttext: Well, certainly -- this is Mike, certainly, the portion of the product assortment in which we delivered new -- greater newness at a greater piece is in fashion product. And I think we've seen the sales results to the extent that fashion has grown faster, so we certainly continue our emphasis on that segment of the assortment. We've also had increased success with sales under the $500 price point. And once again, as we indicated on the call, we've stabilized that segment and we hope to grow it. We have put -- we have begun to put into place many of the innovations that we spoke of earlier to bring product to market. It's still relatively early stages, but we're seeing progress in the speed of bringing product to market and the efficiency with which we do it. And then, of course, most importantly, the arrival of Reed several weeks ago, we believe will be yet another way to increase the pace of newness and new product introduction. So at this point, we're feeling good about 2017 and beyond.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We're also very pleased with the progress we're making in our jewelry research design center and we expect to have that fully online by the end of this fiscal year.
componenttext: We're also very pleased with the progress we're making in our jewelry research design center and we expect to have that fully online by the end of this fiscal year.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We're definitely adding more resources in the whole product development -- design and development area, and you'll see it play out over the course of the next year.
componenttext: We're definitely adding more resources in the whole product development -- design and development area, and you'll see it play out over the course of the next year.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

componenttext: We'll go next to the line Lorraine Hutchinson of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: When you talk about increasing the pace of newness, how should we be tracking that? Is it a number of new collections, number of products? And then will Reed's impact to these sales by holiday, will you be able to get some products in the stores by then?
componenttext: When you talk about increasing the pace of newness, how should we be tracking that? Is it a number of new collections, number of products? And then will Reed's impact to these sales by holiday, will you be able to get some products in the stores by then?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. Mike again. Absolutely. There's a number of individual new products and collections in work. You'll certainly see some of Reed's impact in holiday. Specifically, you'll see luxury collections, accessories which are very, very exciting. Th
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. Mike again. Absolutely. There's a number of individual new products and collections in work. You'll certainly see some of Reed's impact in holiday. Specifically, you'll see luxury collections, accessories which are very, very exciting. The non-jewelry collection, you'll see that on or around November. But I think you'll manifest you'll see the new product -- the pace of new product introduction manifest itself both ways, both in individual new products, important new collections, categories like a luxury accessories, of course, the important watch introduction in the second half of the year and, obviously, jewelry collection.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Lorraine, as we've historically said, new jewelry designs in any one year represent less than 10% of our sales in that year. The objective is ultimately to raise that to more than 10%.
componenttext: And Lorraine, as we've historically said, new jewelry designs in any one year represent less than 10% of our sales in that year. The objective is ultimately to raise that to more than 10%.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Oliver Chen with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We'll go next to Oliver Chen with Cowen and Company.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We had a longer-term question in relation to the supply chain. What are your thoughts regarding capacity utilization and your philosophy regarding vertical integration and the opportunities you see and as that relates to what you've been on a really good
componenttext: We had a longer-term question in relation to the supply chain. What are your thoughts regarding capacity utilization and your philosophy regarding vertical integration and the opportunities you see and as that relates to what you've been on a really good journey with the net working capital management? And as we -- another topic with IT, I was just curious from a consumer-facing perspective, what features are you looking for to having in terms of what consumers are demanding and what capabilities will be different in terms of what you're looking for over the next few years.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. I'll try to answer it in the order in which it was presented. So with respect to the supply chain, you're right. We're very pleased with the vertically integrated nature of our supply chain. It does a number of things for us, whic
componenttext: Thanks for the question. I'll try to answer it in the order in which it was presented. So with respect to the supply chain, you're right. We're very pleased with the vertically integrated nature of our supply chain. It does a number of things for us, which is control the quality of the offering, which is to control the pace and the speed of innovation which we're going to be accelerating, ramping up further with a jewelry research design center which allows us to do fast prototyping and also allow us to get really tight on the design specs so we can do a lot of design cost element work by the front which we are very pleased by. We have been looking at ways of for us to maximize the efficiency of the team that we have in all areas, and we've been doing a lot of additional training which is allowing us to cross use the capacity that we do have within our internal system more efficiently and more effectively each and every year. So we're very pleased with what we're seeing on the supply chain side. With respect to IT, it's an area of clear focus for us. We've been investing a lot behind it. We're confident that we're going to be bringing forward are a lot of additional capability that the consumer is going to be the direct beneficiary of. As far as what we're focusing on right now, a lot of it has to do with client telling and a lot of it has to do with our digital capabilities to make the shopping experience more seamless for the customers all around the world.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And I had a quick question. Lady Gaga was an exciting kind of aspect to the brand. From a newness perspective, what are you thinking about how you're thinking about customers in terms of what you want to target, what's the opportunity and thinking about s
componenttext: And I had a quick question. Lady Gaga was an exciting kind of aspect to the brand. From a newness perspective, what are you thinking about how you're thinking about customers in terms of what you want to target, what's the opportunity and thinking about self purchasing versus gifting as you make -- as you drive a lot of innovation in your portfolio and marketing?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think it certainly is true that self-purchase and gifting must move forward together. As you know, self-purchase -- greater degrees of self-purchase has always been part of -- has been an objective of this company for many, many years. And I think to th
componenttext: I think it certainly is true that self-purchase and gifting must move forward together. As you know, self-purchase -- greater degrees of self-purchase has always been part of -- has been an objective of this company for many, many years. And I think to the extent that we're seeing relative strength in our fashion collections and individual fashion items, it means that we're making progress and we're going to continue to make that a focus. And at the same time, our investment in luxury collections, luxury accessories and the gifting component of that also is critically important. We think that's important because it's necessary to drive traffic into our stores, so we intend to move forward on all those fronts.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Brian Nagel lives Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll go next to Brian Nagel lives Oppenheimer.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: So the first question I have, just with respect to guidance, the initial guidance you put out for 2017. If I look at those and other figures, particularly top line numbers, it does assume a better trend that we've seen recently at the chain. I know we've
componenttext: So the first question I have, just with respect to guidance, the initial guidance you put out for 2017. If I look at those and other figures, particularly top line numbers, it does assume a better trend that we've seen recently at the chain. I know we've talked a lot in the prepared comments in response to some of the questions about the newness, but how should we think about the drivers of that improved top line? Are there key factors that, that sort of say relies upon? And then the second question is how is the cadence of sales through the year? Do you expect better sales in the year? Or should it be relatively spread out throughout the year?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Brian, it's Mark. We're not talking about the cadence for the year, no quarterly guidance, so you got to make your own assumptions on that. But clearly, with all of the initiatives that are happening here, in terms of better engaging customers, and we're
componenttext: Brian, it's Mark. We're not talking about the cadence for the year, no quarterly guidance, so you got to make your own assumptions on that. But clearly, with all of the initiatives that are happening here, in terms of better engaging customers, and we're talking about product development, and here, we're talking about the exciting innovations and marketing communication, we have to make some assumptions. And we think with all of these things happening, we ought to be able to perform a little bit better than we did in 2016.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And let me just add that returning here 5 or so weeks ago, I've been terribly impressed by the number of initiatives. Again, they're in various stages of development, but there's an awful lot going on around here in terms of improving the store experience
componenttext: And let me just add that returning here 5 or so weeks ago, I've been terribly impressed by the number of initiatives. Again, they're in various stages of development, but there's an awful lot going on around here in terms of improving the store experience, the Tiffany touch customer service program, better goal setting and measurement Art Deco the Tiffany experience index, which measures client satisfaction. There's an awful lot happening. And of course, as we've spoken, now -- some new pace of product introduction. So I think we're reasonably confident that the goals that we've set in terms of sales in 2017 are, in fact, achievable.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And I guess can I follow up with one question? With respect to -- obviously more focus on the U.S. business domestic business but there's a lot of chatter out there within retail about the impact of declining mall traffic. I'm recognizing Tiffany's locate
componenttext: And I guess can I follow up with one question? With respect to -- obviously more focus on the U.S. business domestic business but there's a lot of chatter out there within retail about the impact of declining mall traffic. I'm recognizing Tiffany's located in the better malls. But nonetheless are -- is the declining mall traffic at all something that's affecting the Tiffany business?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I mean yes, I made one of the reasons that -- of course it is. We're certainly not immune to that. And as we've said earlier, one of the reasons that we're excited about the luxury accessories collection, the gift collection because it's designed very spe
componenttext: I mean yes, I made one of the reasons that -- of course it is. We're certainly not immune to that. And as we've said earlier, one of the reasons that we're excited about the luxury accessories collection, the gift collection because it's designed very specifically to drive traffic into the Tiffany stores, as you know, that's a business that we walked away from slowly but consistently over the past 10 years, and we think it's time to put that back. So we think that, that can help traffic. And finally again, improvements in the store experience itself. We're not immune to the declines in store traffic, but we think we have to -- it's up to us to do something about it on an individual store business whatever may be happening in the mall.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We're also working proactively to make sure that Tiffany's is relevant and accessible wherever shoppers happen to be. So our cruiseship initiative as an example is a way for to make sure that we are evolving with the current times.
componenttext: We're also working proactively to make sure that Tiffany's is relevant and accessible wherever shoppers happen to be. So our cruiseship initiative as an example is a way for to make sure that we are evolving with the current times.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Lindsay Drucker Mann with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Lindsay Drucker Mann with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just one quick one for me first, and then I have a follow-up. Did the timing of Chinese New Year help your -- it appeared that your January accelerated from your holiday. Did the timing of Chinese New Year help at all to potentially impact your first quar
componenttext: Just one quick one for me first, and then I have a follow-up. Did the timing of Chinese New Year help your -- it appeared that your January accelerated from your holiday. Did the timing of Chinese New Year help at all to potentially impact your first quarter?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, the shift has -- that refers to January. It happened on the first quarter, but clearly, if we had some benefit in late January, it worked the other way in early February.
componenttext: Yes, the shift has -- that refers to January. It happened on the first quarter, but clearly, if we had some benefit in late January, it worked the other way in early February.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And Mark, I wanted to ask just now that you have been in the seat for a little bit of time and have had a chance to really think deeply about -- you've talked about wanting to help improve efficiency at the business. Could you talk about some
componenttext: Okay, great. And Mark, I wanted to ask just now that you have been in the seat for a little bit of time and have had a chance to really think deeply about -- you've talked about wanting to help improve efficiency at the business. Could you talk about some of the specific initiatives? I know you talked a bit about this, some new order management systems. But anything else as you think about the strategies for 2017 and how you can improve the inventory efficiency or optimize the cost structure that would be helpful?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: No. Thank you very much for the question. I mean as with Mike, he made a comment that he was very pleased to see an enormous number of initiatives that were being actioned when he kind of parachuted back in. I would tell you that there was a lot of things
componenttext: No. Thank you very much for the question. I mean as with Mike, he made a comment that he was very pleased to see an enormous number of initiatives that were being actioned when he kind of parachuted back in. I would tell you that there was a lot of things being done in a lot of good regards by a lot of really talented people which I'm going to now partial beneficiary along with all the shareholders that are out there and those of you on the call today. A lot of this is just basic blocking and tackling. We have a global procurement group that's relatively early in its formation which are doing simply good work. We have to get our arms around those global spend goals where we will negotiate harder and better with more visibility and more impact. That's the key initiative I mentioned earlier the jewelry design center. I don't want to overplay it, but I certainly don't want to undersell it either, the new fast prototyping on the idea and that Reed and his team are generating is going to put as well down the path of being able to design for efficiency in all of our internal processes. And frankly, it will also allow us for those items that we do choose put up to external bid be a lot tighter in that process as well. Clearly, the systems that we have available to us today are going to be optimized in the years ahead, and that's going to allow us to do better assortment planning. With better assortment planning, we'll be better to do more high level analytics that goes along with that. We'll be able to get pricing in a lot more discrete ways and we're going to be able to make sure that each store we have the right product at the right time or as much as practical versus what we have today. We have several pretty exciting initiatives all earmarked in that regard. The planned structure, as I indicated earlier, is also doing a lot of really good work to cross-train so that we have the ability to do multiple operation multiple sites, and that's allowing us to extract a lot more value. And we're starting to play with some different technologies as well, which we think over time leads to some additional productivity gains. SO there's a broad-based back to the things that we're aggressively pursuing. And I'm confident that we're going to be able to affect our cost structures in a favorable way which will allow them to view additional monies into other investment areas going forward.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the inventory side, I know there were many years where Tiffany was lengthening out its inventory, its diamond inventory in order to safeguard against the shortage in supply. And obviously, diamond markets are a little bit different today than back then
componenttext: On the inventory side, I know there were many years where Tiffany was lengthening out its inventory, its diamond inventory in order to safeguard against the shortage in supply. And obviously, diamond markets are a little bit different today than back then. Is there an opportunity to extract more efficiency out of your diamond inventories by taking a less conservative approach to the need to have inventory on hand?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The short answer is yes, and that's what we're actively engaged in as well. I'm trying to make sure that we're getting the right collection of rought stones and then being able to quickly and efficiently process of those is obviously an area of focus for
componenttext: The short answer is yes, and that's what we're actively engaged in as well. I'm trying to make sure that we're getting the right collection of rought stones and then being able to quickly and efficiently process of those is obviously an area of focus for us.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, that building up of the diamond supply chain was a 10-year process and we're done. We're maxed out and now there's an opportunity to identify ways to improve it.
componenttext: No. I mean, that building up of the diamond supply chain was a 10-year process and we're done. We're maxed out and now there's an opportunity to identify ways to improve it.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Bob Drbul with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: We'll go next to Bob Drbul with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

componenttext: Mike, welcome back.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

componenttext: Thank you, Bob.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, question that I have is, can you comment a little bit about how January -- the flagship store in January and your assumptions into '17 around the flagship store?
componenttext: I guess, question that I have is, can you comment a little bit about how January -- the flagship store in January and your assumptions into '17 around the flagship store?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's Mark. I'll just mention that in January, the flagship store technically did very well, but that was really driven by a couple of very large one-off transactions. So we're not going to read too much into that. But technically, that's why you saw
componenttext: Bob, it's Mark. I'll just mention that in January, the flagship store technically did very well, but that was really driven by a couple of very large one-off transactions. So we're not going to read too much into that. But technically, that's why you saw the flagship store down by considerably smaller amount in the fourth quarter versus what it had been in the holiday period. And we're going to plan somewhat cautiously to the New York flagship store in 2017 but we're not going to share our assumptions with you on that store.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And obviously, we're going to continue to work with the secret service and the NYPD to maximize access to the store and minimize the disruption. But as you know, it is largely beyond our control, so we'll do what we can. We also have, obviously, other sto
componenttext: And obviously, we're going to continue to work with the secret service and the NYPD to maximize access to the store and minimize the disruption. But as you know, it is largely beyond our control, so we'll do what we can. We also have, obviously, other stores here in the city which we can -- we'll better utilize as the year progresses.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I guess my second question would be, when you look at the comp leverage point in the business overall, do you see an opportunity to bring that down over the longer term from where we are right now?
componenttext: Okay, and I guess my second question would be, when you look at the comp leverage point in the business overall, do you see an opportunity to bring that down over the longer term from where we are right now?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think you heard us say that with respect to SG&A in 2017, we think SG&A growth as a percent of sales will just be slightly ahead of our sales forecast. So that's something that we're very mindful of and it's something that we're going to be working hard
componenttext: I think you heard us say that with respect to SG&A in 2017, we think SG&A growth as a percent of sales will just be slightly ahead of our sales forecast. So that's something that we're very mindful of and it's something that we're going to be working hard in order to again make sure that we can find all the investment areas that we think can really accelerate the top line for us.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're definitely moving in that direction, Bob, to again to a point where we can resume getting leverage on SG&A.
componenttext: Yes. So we're definitely moving in that direction, Bob, to again to a point where we can resume getting leverage on SG&A.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to a Dana Telsey with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: We'll go next to a Dana Telsey with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Nice to hear the progress that you've been making so far on the product side. And it also sounds like there's progress on the gross margin side. If you look at the opportunities going forward, what are you seeing for product input cost, product input cost
componenttext: Nice to hear the progress that you've been making so far on the product side. And it also sounds like there's progress on the gross margin side. If you look at the opportunities going forward, what are you seeing for product input cost, product input costs and also on the marketing spend? And also, Mike, since you been back, what's the biggest difference from when you left at the operational role?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Real quickly on the input side, what I would tell you is that we've been in a relatively favorable environment as it relates to both metal prices as well as rough and polished diamonds. We expect that to continue through at least the 2017 time horizon. As
componenttext: Real quickly on the input side, what I would tell you is that we've been in a relatively favorable environment as it relates to both metal prices as well as rough and polished diamonds. We expect that to continue through at least the 2017 time horizon. As you know, we have a relatively long supply chain on rough and polished. So a lot of the cost visibility that we have into '17 is basically pretty tight and borne out by things that have already come to pass, so to speak. And with respect to our metals, we can to go out with forwards and lock in our metal pricing as well. So we're pretty confident about the gross margin that we spoke to in the context of our '17 guidance.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Dana, in terms of what's changed, again, as I said a moment ago, and as Mark indicated when he arrived a few months ago, I think I'm not surprised by it, but I'm certainly impressed by the number of initiatives underway both in terms of improved custo
componenttext: And Dana, in terms of what's changed, again, as I said a moment ago, and as Mark indicated when he arrived a few months ago, I think I'm not surprised by it, but I'm certainly impressed by the number of initiatives underway both in terms of improved customer service, the work that's been doing around inventory productivity and efficiency and IT development. And I think most importantly, what hasn't changed is that this culture remains very strong and resilient. And everyone at Tiffany, despite the obvious challenges and some of the changes, continues to be passionate about the brand and confident in our future. Tiffany, most certainly, is one of the world's great luxury brand. It's not broken and everyone here is simply committed more than ever to making it greater. So I feel really good.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Laurent Vasilescu with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll go next to Laurent Vasilescu with Macquarie.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The investment -- [indiscernible] in cost in 2018 I think of which $30 million was posted in the P&L, can you tell us how much flowed through in '16 and how much we should anticipate for '17? And then finally, are there any opportunities to increase that
componenttext: The investment -- [indiscernible] in cost in 2018 I think of which $30 million was posted in the P&L, can you tell us how much flowed through in '16 and how much we should anticipate for '17? And then finally, are there any opportunities to increase that $50 million target beyond '17?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Laurent, it's Mark. In answer to the first part of your question, we're definitely moving in that direction through savings that we've already achieved in the global procurement and savings that are anticipated. We're not going to get more granular than t
componenttext: Laurent, it's Mark. In answer to the first part of your question, we're definitely moving in that direction through savings that we've already achieved in the global procurement and savings that are anticipated. We're not going to get more granular than that in terms of exactly how much it was in 2016 and what that will be 2017 but we're definitely -- targets that we have specified for 2018. And then are there opportunities for cost savings beyond that, I'd turn it to the other Mark here but I think the answer is going to be we're always going to be looking for opportunities to run the business more profitably, more efficiently. Mark?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I completely hear you. As I mentioned a while back, the global procurement initiative is still in its early days and we're finding enormous benefit from the work that's being done in that area, and it's now starting to go into a a lot of areas of the busi
componenttext: I completely hear you. As I mentioned a while back, the global procurement initiative is still in its early days and we're finding enormous benefit from the work that's being done in that area, and it's now starting to go into a a lot of areas of the business whether it's with respect to the store designs, case line, lighting, we're finding enormous opportunities in all those areas. And we're very confident that, as Mark said, we'll be able to achieve the target levels savings that we laid out by the indicated days, if not sooner.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: But also I'll just add. Ultimately, we need better sales growth. I think that's the obvious. And if all of these initiatives we're pursuing can generate better sales growth, combined with what we're working on, on the expense side, that's what will give u
componenttext: But also I'll just add. Ultimately, we need better sales growth. I think that's the obvious. And if all of these initiatives we're pursuing can generate better sales growth, combined with what we're working on, on the expense side, that's what will give us a return to good operating margin improvement.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And as a quick follow-up, your e-commerce sales have been relatively flat over the last 2 years. Are there opportunities for you to get to double-digit percentage of sales? And any update on Net-A-Porter partnership would be appreciated.
componenttext: And as a quick follow-up, your e-commerce sales have been relatively flat over the last 2 years. Are there opportunities for you to get to double-digit percentage of sales? And any update on Net-A-Porter partnership would be appreciated.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say in terms of Net-A-Porter, we've been very pleased with the relationship with them. And it certainly -- guys, feel free to chime in, but it's certainly possible that, that 6% of sales could gradually move up closer to 8% or 10%. Some youn
componenttext: Well, I would say in terms of Net-A-Porter, we've been very pleased with the relationship with them. And it certainly -- guys, feel free to chime in, but it's certainly possible that, that 6% of sales could gradually move up closer to 8% or 10%. Some younger customers certainly opt more for shopping online so they'll use our website more. But everything is going to be a very large number because it's not the nature of our business.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Although we give an accessories, luxury accessories a revamp that were underway, that will lend itself we think to more e-commerce transaction by nature.
componenttext: Although we give an accessories, luxury accessories a revamp that were underway, that will lend itself we think to more e-commerce transaction by nature.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's an critically important point. The disappointing sales growth in e-commerce over the year, I think more than any years -- recent years, more than anything else is a function of merchandising assortment. And the fact that we have not ha
componenttext: Yes, I think that's an critically important point. The disappointing sales growth in e-commerce over the year, I think more than any years -- recent years, more than anything else is a function of merchandising assortment. And the fact that we have not had growth in lower price point jewelry and of course there's been an absence of gifts. Those gifts are being put back active product development in silver -- in jewelry under $500, and that should have an important impact on our ability to grow e-commerce sales because that's the heart of that business.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can go through some of the revenue growth drivers that you've got in place. I know there are a lot of macro factors impacting Tiffany's sales growth, but knowing that there are certain aspects of sales growth that are in your control,
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can go through some of the revenue growth drivers that you've got in place. I know there are a lot of macro factors impacting Tiffany's sales growth, but knowing that there are certain aspects of sales growth that are in your control, I think you've got a number of different strategies in place. I think one would be the pace of innovation. You mentioned some development of additional service metrics in the stores. Could you just maybe tick through the 2 or 3 or 4 or 5 different revenue growth strategies that you've got in place?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: You've already touched on a few that are critically important, so let me just add. Certainly, enhanced client telling efforts that are going to be informed by our new CSR systems, something -- somewhat operational but will have an impact on the sales woul
componenttext: You've already touched on a few that are critically important, so let me just add. Certainly, enhanced client telling efforts that are going to be informed by our new CSR systems, something -- somewhat operational but will have an impact on the sales would be more intelligent client-focused staffing programs in all of our stores. We're working very hard to improve the store experience both around better assortments and creative visual merchandising. Again, I think you referenced, I referenced also that Tiffany touch customer service program. I think so much of the effort around -- in addition to obvious new product development and the pace of new product development really is going to be built around enhancing all of the engines of the customer in-store experience.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

componenttext: As Mark said CSR, he meant CRM.

componenttext: CRM.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Betty Chen with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: We'll go next to Betty Chen with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit more about the [indiscernible]. It seems like you saw jewelry unit growth there in 2016 for the quarter. Also said that Hong Kong may have seen some sequential improvement maybe if you can share your thoughts o
componenttext: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit more about the [indiscernible]. It seems like you saw jewelry unit growth there in 2016 for the quarter. Also said that Hong Kong may have seen some sequential improvement maybe if you can share your thoughts on that region. And also longer term, any updates on how you view the Mainland China opportunity and any learnings from some of the initial foray on how to maybe accelerate some of that growth?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the last part of your question because it's the easiest. We certainly see the Mainland, if I can use that term, Mainland China opportunity as continuing to be very, very significant. Again, the brand is still in its early -- relatively e
componenttext: Let me start with the last part of your question because it's the easiest. We certainly see the Mainland, if I can use that term, Mainland China opportunity as continuing to be very, very significant. Again, the brand is still in its early -- relatively early stages of development in that market. We have good awareness, but lots of opportunity to improve awareness, lots of opportunity to optimize the store network. So I think we're as optimistic as we've ever been about the opportunities in Greater China.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, and in terms of your question about unit growth, jewelry unit volume growth in Asia Pacific doing the year, part of it was just core better growth but a lot of it was due to the fact that we opened a number of new stores. So that unit growth is not o
componenttext: Yes, and in terms of your question about unit growth, jewelry unit volume growth in Asia Pacific doing the year, part of it was just core better growth but a lot of it was due to the fact that we opened a number of new stores. So that unit growth is not on a comp store basis but on a total region basis, total sales basis. But nonetheless, we were pleased with it. And then in terms of Hong Kong, as everyone knows, Hong Kong really softened almost 2.5 years ago, started in October 2014. But finally, in 2016, we started to see some improvement, still down but certainly getting less bad from quarter-to-quarter. And at one point, it will completely bottom up and start growing is anybody's guess, but we certainly think that the worst part is probably behind us and we're getting closer to stabilization there.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, and my second question, if I could, is last call, you mentioned a lot of units under $500 I think maybe up 10% or so. Any sort of material increase in 2017 or 2018 that we should think about in that category especially since it seems to be an import
componenttext: Okay, and my second question, if I could, is last call, you mentioned a lot of units under $500 I think maybe up 10% or so. Any sort of material increase in 2017 or 2018 that we should think about in that category especially since it seems to be an important area for not only in-store but also online as well?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll be innovating across all categories in 2017 and 2018. There'll be newness in silver, gold, platinum, diamonds, so we're not going to get too technical in terms of how we're dividing up our newness by category or biomaterial, but there'll certa
componenttext: Well, we'll be innovating across all categories in 2017 and 2018. There'll be newness in silver, gold, platinum, diamonds, so we're not going to get too technical in terms of how we're dividing up our newness by category or biomaterial, but there'll certainly be newness in silver just as there will be across every other category.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Simeon Siegel with Nomura.
componenttext: We'll go next to Simeon Siegel with Nomura.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Mark, it seems like the loan impairments went beyond the -- if that's right, anything we should think about regarding future potential financing impairment? And just maybe taking a step back follow the supply chain commentary, maybe it's still early. But
componenttext: Mark, it seems like the loan impairments went beyond the -- if that's right, anything we should think about regarding future potential financing impairment? And just maybe taking a step back follow the supply chain commentary, maybe it's still early. But as you look through the operations, you've been referring to the aspects of the integration that you're particularly pleased with? Anything you've called out as part of process you might want to have an opportunity in changing.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: With respect to the loans that we had previously made in order to be able to access supply, the good news is that that's all largely passed at this point. We have one loan that's outstanding as a performing loan. And after this quarter, it's very de minim
componenttext: With respect to the loans that we had previously made in order to be able to access supply, the good news is that that's all largely passed at this point. We have one loan that's outstanding as a performing loan. And after this quarter, it's very de minimis, a couple of million dollars and as I said, it's a performing loan. That should be all that remains with us. So we think that we have processed through all of that. With respect to your other question, I don't want to evade it because it's a fair question but I think for me, there's just an abundance of opportunities that -- for us. So a lot of work has been done, a lot of really good work has been done. But that said and despite the fact it's a 180-year-old company, there's still enormous opportunities going forward that we have the ability to access. So maybe one thing I would offer is the state of the IT systems because of the company's rapid growth phase is an opportunity for us now that we have the ability to stitch that together in a seamless way and that's going to give us a lot of additional capabilities going forward. So maybe one thing is -- I would have thought that maybe there's a little bit more -- an evolved IT infrastructure and reasons related to the financial cube, but this is something that's easily addressed and we're going to get after in short order, and again, that will be more opportunity.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Janet Kloppenburg with JJK Research.
componenttext: We'll go next to Janet Kloppenburg with JJK Research.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Welcome back, Mike.
componenttext: Welcome back, Mike.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

componenttext: Hey, Janet. Thank you.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just ask a question about the mix of business. It sounds like the silver business is stabilizing and the fashion jewelry business is improving. And I'm wondering if you're encouraged, Mike, that, that mix can continue to be favorable and that
componenttext: I wanted to just ask a question about the mix of business. It sounds like the silver business is stabilizing and the fashion jewelry business is improving. And I'm wondering if you're encouraged, Mike, that, that mix can continue to be favorable and that you had a turning point in the fashion jewelry business. And for Mark, I was wondering how influential that would be to the gross margin as we look into fiscal '17 and whether or not you think you'd be able to generate the same level of gross margin improvement in '17 as was seen in '16. And just lastly, Mike, or Mark, whoever, on marketing, the legendary campaign launched in the fall, I was wondering if there's any way to discuss the effectiveness of that campaign in reaching the millennial customer, how well it resonated and if the program will move forward.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Let me try to answer the first question, Janet, around the overall going forward direction of product assortment, product category. As I think everyone on the call knows, part of the magic of Tiffany over the very, very many years has been our ability to
componenttext: Let me try to answer the first question, Janet, around the overall going forward direction of product assortment, product category. As I think everyone on the call knows, part of the magic of Tiffany over the very, very many years has been our ability to balance that -- those categories and to move forward with them all simultaneously. Critical to that has always been our ability to drive lower price point sales because of the very favorable margin profile of that category. And once again, as you've heard before, we've stabilized that segment. We also feel very good about the fashion segment gold -- the fashion part of the segment. And once again, due to the entire mix, that also has favorable gross margin profile. So I think we're not finished certainly, but right now we're feeling relatively good about the direction of category evolution. And of course, as we've said now many times on the phone, we have the work in progress on watches which we're pleased with and, of course, the upcoming gift collection which also should be additive incremental to gross margin. So on that score, a product balance, relative category growth going forward, we're in a pretty good spot right now.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And what I would offer is, the other thing you asked questions about gross margin in things, we really focused on operating margin. We really were trying to put together a sustainable business model which is you got about 50 basis points on the operating
componenttext: And what I would offer is, the other thing you asked questions about gross margin in things, we really focused on operating margin. We really were trying to put together a sustainable business model which is you got about 50 basis points on the operating like each and every year. Certainly, within our product offerings, certain groupings within that have higher gross margins than others, silver fashion, as an example. That said, we enjoy pretty attractive gross margins in the absolute across all of our product offerings. And I don't want us to become fixated on gross margin as it relates to product mix because at the end of the day, I'm happy to sell an incremental item across any of our offerings a because in the absolute, they're very accretive and attractive to us. So product mix does play into it, but I don't want to overplay the role of that in our overall business model.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And certainly, we're going to continue to try to drive sales of high jewelry because, again, our -- are not as robust as they are as in other parts of the product spectrum. On the margin, they're just wonderful. So we have no problem enjoying the success
componenttext: And certainly, we're going to continue to try to drive sales of high jewelry because, again, our -- are not as robust as they are as in other parts of the product spectrum. On the margin, they're just wonderful. So we have no problem enjoying the success from those sorts of sales. And finally, Janet, the last question about the millennials and the advertising campaign, I don't know. That's always a difficult, unanswerable, difficult-to-know question. But as some quantitative evidence, I would simply point out that, again, it's the fashion categories, where we've enjoyed the most relative success, I think that speaks, at least directionally, of some success in improving and appealing to millennials.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
