componenttext: We'll go next to Brian Tunick with Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess for Mike, I was just curious about your new board members, your new investors, what in your mind do you think the new board members bring to the table? And maybe what could be the timing of their influence on strategy for the business?
componenttext: I guess for Mike, I was just curious about your new board members, your new investors, what in your mind do you think the new board members bring to the table? And maybe what could be the timing of their influence on strategy for the business?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, in terms of timing, they're already at the table. We had our first board meeting, which was a very productive, helpful meeting. Certainly, the new directors, collectively, they bring a wealth of -- obviously, a wealth of highly relevant e
componenttext: Well, certainly, in terms of timing, they're already at the table. We had our first board meeting, which was a very productive, helpful meeting. Certainly, the new directors, collectively, they bring a wealth of -- obviously, a wealth of highly relevant experience and expertise, whether its consumer product, luxury and lifestyle products and, obviously, retailing. I don't think that, as we said a couple of weeks ago, we still -- we feel very, very confident in the fundamental strategic direction of the company. So I'm not -- from my perspective, not especially looking for a dramatic, left or right turns in our strategies. I think they, along with the entire board, will help evolve our strategic direction, and again, we're confident that they will all contribute importantly to that.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Paul with Citi.
componenttext: We'll go next to Paul with Citi.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's Jen in for Paul. Two quick ones if I may. First wondering if you could talk a little bit about January comp improvement beyond the Fifth Avenue flagship, what you saw in kind of the rest of America and Europe and Asia-Pacific where trends also improv
componenttext: It's Jen in for Paul. Two quick ones if I may. First wondering if you could talk a little bit about January comp improvement beyond the Fifth Avenue flagship, what you saw in kind of the rest of America and Europe and Asia-Pacific where trends also improved versus holiday? And then secondly, I think you said that we'll start to see some of Reed's luxury accessories in November. I was wondering if we've started to see some of it already and we'll start to see it more in November or if we should -- if we won't see anything until November. And gross margins on that category, should we think of them as being higher than some of the other categories?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, it will be November for the introduction of the full-on jewelry luxury gift collection. Margins are attractive. And in terms of January trends, we did say that things were slightly better in the U.S. Part of that is just coming from the big transact
componenttext: Well, it will be November for the introduction of the full-on jewelry luxury gift collection. Margins are attractive. And in terms of January trends, we did say that things were slightly better in the U.S. Part of that is just coming from the big transactions in the New York flagship store. And we did already mention that we had some shift from the earlier Chinese New Year that benefited some business in Asia, and so -- but we're not going to get more specific than that. So January came in a little bit better than we had expected, and we planned accordingly for 2017.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

componenttext: We'll go next to Irwin Boruchow with Wells Fargo.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up into Asia-Pacific. I know you're not guiding explicitly for the region, but I was just curious embedded in your outlook, are you assuming that the declines in Hong Kong continued to improve a little bit? And then I'm just curious ab
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up into Asia-Pacific. I know you're not guiding explicitly for the region, but I was just curious embedded in your outlook, are you assuming that the declines in Hong Kong continued to improve a little bit? And then I'm just curious about how you view the change in travel in terms of Korea and China and how that's changing and how that might impact the business on the mainland?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're assuming that at some point, business in Hong Kong will stabilize without getting more specific than that, but we said in 2016, we saw it sequentially getting better and we hope that we continue to see that in 2017. And it would certainly be ve
componenttext: Yes, we're assuming that at some point, business in Hong Kong will stabilize without getting more specific than that, but we said in 2016, we saw it sequentially getting better and we hope that we continue to see that in 2017. And it would certainly be very nice at some point to talk about it flattening out but not yet. And in terms of Chinese tourist travel and Korea, we'll see. It's a little bit early to make a call on the implications of that, but again, we're pretty comfortable in dealing with the dynamics of a tourist movement around the world, so we'll see how that will develop. We certainly got a strong position in Korea, a strong store base.

componenttext: I'm wondering if you could provide some perspective on your e-commerce business and how that's evolving, how that's trending as a percentage of sales, and what kind of initiatives you have for 2017 on that business?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And I think it's important to put it in perspective, relative to our global luxury peers. 6% is probably about average for luxury peers and it's significantly larger than our luxury peers. Having said that, we do believe that, obviously, we'd like to rest
componenttext: And I think it's important to put it in perspective, relative to our global luxury peers. 6% is probably about average for luxury peers and it's significantly larger than our luxury peers. Having said that, we do believe that, obviously, we'd like to restart growth. And again, I think the key, as I said before, the key to that segment or that distribution channel really is going to be about product innovation and development. So I think I'll leave it at that.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Randy Konik with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Randy Konik with Jefferies.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: So a couple of questions. I guess, one on the product newness factor here. You talked about increasing the pace of newness. Kind of any further color on how you're thinking about that, either from a SKU perspective or an actual category perspective? Becau
componenttext: So a couple of questions. I guess, one on the product newness factor here. You talked about increasing the pace of newness. Kind of any further color on how you're thinking about that, either from a SKU perspective or an actual category perspective? Because when I look historically about over the last 17 years or at least over the last 10, you guys had done a great job when you announced Tiffany T Collection, the keys collection, the marketing around the Celebration Rings? So when you basically come out with the new category, it does very well. And I'm just trying to get a sense of how you're thinking about launching new collections and versus launching just additional SKUs within existing collections. And then lastly, around SKU count, do you think about increasing gross SKU counts but basically leaving net SKU counts flat to increase SKU count productivity? I'm just trying to get a sense of how you think this all plays out from a product newness perspective.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, let me say the obvious. We're not about to proliferate the SKU count. So probably more or less, your suggestion that, combined with the pace of new product introductions, an increased pace of new product, new collection introductions, net SKU count
componenttext: Well, let me say the obvious. We're not about to proliferate the SKU count. So probably more or less, your suggestion that, combined with the pace of new product introductions, an increased pace of new product, new collection introductions, net SKU count probably will stay where it is. It might even need to decline a bit. But the key will be building -- growth is going to come from a combination of one new collection. And if you look at the evolution of our assortment over the past 10 years, far more concentrated today in important collections than it was 10 years ago in multiple smaller collections. So we want new collections but they have to be big and they need to be impactful. And of course, Tiffany T is -- would be the model -- one of the models going forward for that. At the same time, we need to be mindful that existing collections Return to Tiffany Love, they have to be renewed and we have to continue to animate and increase and inject energy into those. So it's going to be, as it always is, a very careful balance of making sure that we have significant new collections that marketing can drive at the same time making sure that the core collections that are still the -- that will always be the majority of sales continue to grow at the same time. So it's a complex balancing act.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And can I just ask a follow-up if possible? With Reed, I think that's a great hire, what are your petitions of him? Or what has he seen when he's reviewed the business on how you can better tie product launches to the store look and, importantly, the mark
componenttext: And can I just ask a follow-up if possible? With Reed, I think that's a great hire, what are your petitions of him? Or what has he seen when he's reviewed the business on how you can better tie product launches to the store look and, importantly, the marketing cadence or the marketing look out there with the products on people, et cetera? So how does he -- what's your vision for him? Or what's his a vision for the brand and how to tie it all together since he's more -- his role is kind of in charge of multiple areas, not just product.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think at this point, I'll decline to speak for Reed. He hasn't been here that long, although he's made, from my perspective, tremendous progress. But I think what you said, if I can just repeat that because I think it's critically important for everyone
componenttext: I think at this point, I'll decline to speak for Reed. He hasn't been here that long, although he's made, from my perspective, tremendous progress. But I think what you said, if I can just repeat that because I think it's critically important for everyone on the call, in addition to product design, Reed will need the brand's artistic and design vision with respect to stores, to e-commerce, to marketing, to advertising, where right now, I know, Reed's heavily engaged in looking at that new store prototypes. So I think we're going to look to Reed for, obviously, a comprehensive integrated brand vision. What that brand vision is going to be other than it's not going to be a radical left or right turn from where we are. I think it's going to be a continued evolution of fine-tuning of what we have, but I think it probably would be premature for us to speak about that today.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Tiffany & Co. Fourth Quarter Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Participating on today's call is Mr. Mark Aaron, Vice President and -- of Investor Relations; and Michael Kowalski, Chairman of the Board
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Tiffany & Co. Fourth Quarter Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Participating on today's call is Mr. Mark Aaron, Vice President and -- of Investor Relations; and Michael Kowalski, Chairman of the Board and interim Chief Executive Officer; and Mr. Mark Erceg, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mr. Mark Aaron. Please go ahead.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year 2016 conference call. I'm delighted that Tiffany's Chairman of the Board and interim CEO, Mike Kowalski; and our CFO, Mark Erceg, are on today's call. We'll review actua
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year 2016 conference call. I'm delighted that Tiffany's Chairman of the Board and interim CEO, Mike Kowalski; and our CFO, Mark Erceg, are on today's call. We'll review actual results and comment on the 2017 outlook, and then we'll allow time to answer some questions. 
Before proceeding, please note that statements made on this call that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. Actual results might differ materially from the planned, assumed or expected results expressed in or implied by these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors, risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially is set forth in Tiffany's Form 10-K, 10-Q and 8-K reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the news release filed today under cover of Form 8-K. The company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement to reflect subsequent events or circumstances, except as required by applicable law or regulation. 
Okay. By now, I hope you've had a chance to read today's news release, which indicated fourth quarter and full year results that were in line with the guidance that we've provided in January and reaffirmed last month. Worldwide net sales rose slightly in the fourth quarter, and earnings per diluted share declined slightly. For the full year, worldwide net sales declined 3%, diluted EPS declined 1% on a GAAP basis and 2% when excluding charges in both years. And we managed our balance sheet effectively generating strong cash flow in the year. 
So let's review the results starting with the top line. First, there were no meaningful changes in regional sales mix in 2016 with the Americas representing 46% of worldwide sales, Asia Pacific at 25%, Japan at 15% and Europe at 11%. In the Americas, total sales and comparable store sales declined in both the fourth quarter and the year as a result of lower jewelry units sold. In the U.S., we experienced softness across most of the country for the year, although at lesser rates in some stores as the year progressed. 
In addition to the full year, sales weakness in Canada was partly offset by growth in Latin America. We attributed a portion of the softness in the U.S. throughout the year to local customers, which, we believe, was tied to macro, market and political uncertainties. Sales attributed to foreign visitors declined in the full year, which we attribute to lower spending by Chinese visitors. But we believe total sales benefited in the second half of the year due to increased spending by Japanese tourists. We estimate that U.S. sales in 2016 to foreign tourists remained at approximately 20%. 
We've previously spoken about the impact of postelection activities near our New York flagship store, which represents less than 10% of worldwide sales. While we typically do not discuss individual store results, we are, for at least this quarter, reporting its sales results because of the unique situation and level of investor interest. Sales in the New York flagship declined 11% in the full year and 7% in the entire fourth quarter versus the 14% decline in the November, December holiday period due to some large transactions in January. In addition, we estimate spending by foreign tourists in that store remained at roughly 40% of its annual sales. 
Elsewhere during 2016, we opened one store in Canada in the Holt-Renfrew department store in Toronto, relocated our store in the Holt-Renfrew in Vancouver and relocated our store in the King of Prussia mall outside Philadelphia. Of course, we also continued to renovate many stores, highlighted by magnificent upgrades to our stores in Beverly Hills and San Francisco. 
Turning to Asia Pacific. While total sales were roughly unchanged in the year, we were pleased to see a healthy rate of growth in the second half and fourth quarter that was generated by increases in jewelry units sold. During the year, we were very pleased with strong total and comparable store sales growth in Mainland China as we believe the Tiffany & Co. brand continues to gain recognition and prominence with customers. I should add that lower spending that we attributed to Chinese tourists in other regions in 2016 may have led to some of the higher spending that we saw by local consumers within China. 
Also in the Greater China market, we were pleased to see smaller sequential sales declines in Hong Kong as the year progressed. However, there was noteworthy softness in much of the year in Australia and Taiwan. 
We significantly enhanced our store presence in Asia Pacific in 2016. We opened 7 stores, relocated 2 and closed 3. In China, we opened 3 stores in Ningbo-Heyi, in Tianjin-Hisense and in Shenyang MixC. And we closed 2 stores, one in Beijing in the Peninsula Hotel and one in the Tianjin Friendship store. We finished the year with 31 stores in Mainland China. 
In addition, we opened our 15th store in Korea in the Shinsegae Hanam department store. We opened our first store in New Zealand in Auckland's magnificent Britomart Precinct. And we opened 2 stores in Australia, one in the Gold Coast Pacific Fair and one in the Sydney Airport. In Singapore, we relocated our store at Changi Airport and closed our store in Raffles Hotel. 
In Japan, we achieved healthy retail sales growth in 2016 even excluding the favorable translation benefit from the stronger yen and finished the year on a strong note. We were pleased to have an increase in jewelry units sold in the fourth quarter and full year in Japan that spanned most categories. Anecdotally, we believe our already strong presence in Japan further benefited from the brand exposure we received on a popular television show called For The Romantic, which aired in the July-September time frame. In addition, we believe that the stronger yen has been a factor contributing to the increased purchasing attributed to Japanese tourists that we've experienced in other regions. Conversely, that stronger yen has likely been the reason for less tourist spending in Japan, primarily attributed to Chinese visitors, which reversed the trend we saw in 2015. However, we believe our sales in Japan are made largely by Japanese customers, and we continue to estimate that spending by foreign tourists represented less than 10% of sales in Japan. Lastly in Japan, we had a net reduction of one store in 2016 as we closed the store in the Takashimaya department store in Yonago, while we relocated 2 stores during the year in Nagoya and Kagoshima. 
Conversely, it was a challenging year in Europe. Total sales declined on a reported basis in the fourth quarter and full year, partly reflecting weakening European currencies. On a constant exchange rate basis, total sales declined to a lesser extent in the year and actually rose slightly in the fourth quarter. The sales weakness arose largely from lower jewelry unit volume across all categories. Throughout the year, we experienced varying degrees of soft demands, partly attributed to local customers that, we believe, is the result of economic and political conditions and also attributed to lower spending by foreign tourists, likely tied to the effects of the tragic events in Paris and elsewhere. We estimate that spending attributed to foreign tourists generally represents in the neighborhood of 1/4 to 1/3 of total European sales. In both the fourth quarter and the full year, results were soft across much of Continental Europe, while sales on a constant exchange rate basis in the U.K., which represents roughly 40% of European sales -- sales rose in the U.K. which represents about 40% of European sales. In fact, we believe the sales lift that we saw in the U.K. in the second half of the year was from spending attributed to foreign tourists after the British pound declined following the Brexit vote. We opened 3 stores in Europe in 2016, including 2 in Italy on Rome's Via dei Condotti and in Venice, and a second store in Amsterdam in De Bijenkorf department store. And we closed a small store in the Frankfurt Airport. 
I commented several times on the significant spending attributed to foreign tourists in most regions. In general, tourism flows up from one region to another may be affected by changes in currency values as well as geopolitical and other external factors. Therefore, we believe that creating and reinforcing local and global brand recognition is most relevant to growing our business regardless of where the spending might occur in the short term. 
Lastly, lower sales in our other segment in both the fourth quarter and full year resulted from comp store sales declines in our 5 stores in the United Arab Emirates. Wholesale sales of diamonds increased in the full year, but were roughly unchanged in the fourth quarter. 
In terms of store productivity, worldwide gross -- worldwide sales per gross square foot for company-operated stores was $2,700 in 2016 compared with $2,900 in 2015, resulting from the 3% increase in worldwide gross square footage and a modest worldwide sales decline. By region, sales productivity in 2016 ranged from $3,800 in Asia Pacific to $3,700 in Japan to $2,500 in Europe and to $2,200 in the Americas. Keep in mind that these productivity levels are calculated in U.S. dollars. And therefore, year-to-year differences also reflect foreign currency changes. 
Our strategies partly revolve around optimizing our worldwide store base through openings, relocations, renovations and closings. We expect this to result in increasing global square footage by approximately 2% a year for the foreseeable future. This initiative goes hand in hand with our strategy to more proactively reach customers to deliver a more engaging shopping experience, to deepen long-term relationships with customers and, ultimately, to increase the frequency of store visits and conversion rates. 
Beyond the Tiffany & Co. stores we operate in 28 countries, we also serve customers through e-commerce-enabled websites in 13 of those countries. Worldwide e-commerce sales were approximately unchanged in the year and continued to represent 6% of Tiffany's worldwide sales, but were somewhat higher percentage in the U.S. alone. As we've said many times, our website serves an important dual function of generating online sales, but also in delivering marketing communication that drives awareness and store traffic. That covers regional sales results. 
Looking at the product side. From a sales perspective, trends indicated general softness across all jewelry categories to varying degrees. Despite that, there were some noteworthy product-related highlights in 2016. During the year, we introduced some new designs, refreshed some existing collections and, importantly, have said that we intend to accelerate the pace of newness going forward. Relative improvements that we've seen in fashion jewelry sales can be attributed to higher gold jewelry sales, exemplified by the T collection, which we have continued to build upon with new designs. We also saw a relative improvement in fashion silver jewelry in 2016, led by the popularity of the new Return to Tiffany Love collection with silver jewelry sales approaching stabilization after years of decline. We focused on product newness in silver jewelry in 2016 and grew the number of new items under $500 by more than 10%. 
I should also mention success in our designer jewelry category, which we are now disclosing on its own, driven by Elsa Peretti's jewelry collections highlighted in 2016 by her exquisite Diamonds by the Yard and the open heart designs and the designs of Paloma Picasso, highlighted by her popular Olive Leaf and her new Paloma's Melody collection. 
Engagement jewelry and wedding bands category posted mixed sales performance by region during the year, although we were pleased to see unit volume growth in the quarter and the full year on a worldwide basis. Relatively speaking, the softness product category was high fine and solitaire jewelry. We continue to be pleased with the success of our Victoria collections in platinum and diamonds. However, there was some softness at the highest end of this category. We had held our Blue Book event this spring attended by a global audience as we do every year. And the results, while strong, did not measure up to the huge success of those events in the prior 2 years. You should note that the term high jewelry now replaces the former term statement jewelry. 
Lastly, I'll just mention that we continue to see healthy sales growth in the watch category in 2016. While watch sales have grown, albeit off at a low single-digit percentage of sales base, we see considerable opportunity over the longer term to expand that business through a combination of product development and marketing communications.
That covers the top line review. I'm now pleased to turn the call over to Mark Erceg.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and welcome, everyone. Let me start by stating that while fourth quarter and full year GAAP and adjusted diluted earnings per share both were in line with our expectations, Tiffany's financial performance over the past couple of years has be
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and welcome, everyone. Let me start by stating that while fourth quarter and full year GAAP and adjusted diluted earnings per share both were in line with our expectations, Tiffany's financial performance over the past couple of years has been disappointing, which is why I'm so pleased to be working with Mike Kowalski, the board and all Tiffany's dedicated and talented employees to accelerate the execution of our key strategies in the years ahead. 
One of those strategies is expanding our e-commerce and omnichannel capabilities, which require us to upgrade certain IT systems. So I want to briefly comment on the $25.4 million impairment of capitalized software development costs we recognized in the fourth quarter of 2016. Simply put, as part of a comprehensive system review, we identified a solution, which negated the need to install a separate inventory management and merchandising system, which work had already begun on. By further leveraging our existing ERP system and in order management system we were in the process of implementing, we expect to be able to access the full range of capabilities we are originally seeking, but at a lower cost. This project, now that it has been recast, along with the rapid investments we are making in information systems will, we believe, make our supply chain more efficient, improve the customers' in-store experience and generate incremental sales by expanding and leveraging both our CRM and omnichannel capabilities. 
Let's now look at the rest of the income statement. Gross margin for the fourth quarter was 64.1%, which was up 110 basis points versus a year ago. In fact, gross margin increased year-over-year in every quarter as we benefited from favorable product input costs, 2015 pricing actions, which carried over into 2016 and a favorable shift in product sales mix. For the full year, gross margin was 62.2% versus 60.7% last year. But unfortunately, the 150 basis points of gross margin expansion generated during 2016 was more than offset by increases in SG&A expense. SG&A expense as a percent of sales for the fourth quarter was 43.2%, up 170 basis points versus a year ago. And for the year, it was 44.2%, which was up 200 basis points. The increases in SG&A expense as a percent of sales reflected sales deleveraging due to higher store occupancy and depreciation costs as well as higher labor and incentive compensation costs. Lowering the rate of SG&A expense growth as a percent of sales remains a top priority for the company going forward. 
Marketing spending as a percent of sales was roughly unchanged from the prior year. We continue to broaden Tiffany's presence in a variety of media and, as an example, appeared on television in February with our first Super Bowl commercial. The 62nd ad, which ran 10 key markets, featured Lady Gaga in order to set the stage for our new hardware jewelry collection, which is launching next month. 
Net interest and other expenses in the fourth quarter and for the full year were below prior year due to both reduced foreign currency transaction losses and lower interest expense. Tiffany's full year effective tax rate was 34.1%, which was down from last year's rate of 34.7% due to the favorable impact from the conclusion of a tax examination in the first quarter. 
Turning to the balance sheet and statement of cash flow. We finished the year with reasonable debt levels and generated strong cash flow, both of which gives us the ability to continue investing in our business while also returning excess cash to shareholders. Inventory finished the year 3% below a year ago at $2.2 billion. Accounts receivable at January 31 were 10% higher than the previous year-end with the increase partly tied to the timing of collections driven by sales growth in Japan since the majority of our stores' net market are operated within department stores. A portion of the increase was also currency related. 
Capital expenditures for the year came in at $223 million with more than half of the spending related to the opening, renovation and/or relocation of stores. CapEx represented approximately 6% of worldwide sales during both 2016 and 2015. 
It's also worth pointing out that we made an unplanned and voluntary contribution of $120 million to Tiffany's U.S. pension plan during the fourth quarter of 2016. We expect this to lower our 2017 pension expense as a result of incremental returns expected to be generated on the investments made with that contribution and lower premiums owed to the PBGC. 
Putting it all together we generated $702 million of operating cash flow and $479 million of free cash flow in 2016 after giving effect to the $120 million voluntary pension contribution. Importantly, this was well above our initial goal of generating at least $400 million [ph] of free cash flow for the year. In terms of share repurchases, we spent $184 million and bought more than 2 million shares in 2016. 
Turning to dividends. We increased the quarterly dividend by 12.5% in May, which marked the 15th dividend increase in the past 14 years. We finished fiscal 2016 with $986 million of cash and short-term investments versus $1.1 billion of short-term and long-term debt. So total debt represented just 37% of stockholders' equity, which was unchanged from the prior year. Tiffany's return on assets was 9% and return on stockholders' equity was 15%, both of which are generally consistent with our long-term objectives, which call for a return on assets of at least 10% and a return on equity of at least 15%. 
Looking into 2017. Our financial expectations recognize 2 import external challenges. First, we remain mindful of economic and geopolitical uncertainties, and their potential effects on both local and forest -- foreign tourist spending. Second, since over half our sales continue to be outside the United States, and we expect the U.S. dollar to be stronger on average than the prior year, we should be facing a sizable headwind in terms of translating our non-U.S. sales into dollars. In addition, we'll have to overcome the negative effect of stronger dollar we have on foreign tourists spending in the United States. Of course, we do openly acknowledge that we will partly benefit from the translation effect of non-U.S. expenses into dollars, but that positive impact is expected to be relatively minor compared to the 2 foreign exchange headwinds I just mentioned. 
We plan to open 11 stores in 2017, half in Asia Pacific, relocate 9 and close 6, representing a net 3% increase in global square footage. As part of our strategy to optimize the global store base, we will also continue to renovate some of our existing stores. With this in mind, we expect total sales to increase by a low single-digit percentage over the prior year which, importantly, translates into a mid-single-digit increase over the prior year on a constant exchange rate basis. 
Moving further into the P&L. Our 2017 outlook assumes an increase in operating margin entirely due to an increase in gross margin, with SG&A expense growth just slightly higher than sales growth. The assumption of a higher gross margin is tied to favorable product input costs and proactive expense management. In addition, after not taking any meaningful price increases in 2016, except for currency changes, we took modest price increases in the past month that vary by country, but averaged out to a low single-digit increase on a worldwide basis. 
Our 2017 outlook further assumes interest and other expenses net of approximately $40 million, an effective tax rate consistent with the prior year and that we continue buying shares under our existing share repurchase program, although we expect minimal benefit to diluted earnings per share from the currently planned repurchases. 
Taking all this into account, our outlook falls for net earnings per diluted share to increase by a high single-digit percentage from last year's $3.55 per share on a GAAP basis and to increase by a mid-single-digit percentage over the adjusted $3.75 per share last year. We also plan to manage the balance sheet efficiently with the particular focus on not growing net inventories in order to generate net cash from operating activities of approximately $700 million and free cash flow of approximately $450 million for the full year. The difference of $250 million represents our planned capital expenditures. 
I'm now pleased to turn the call over to Mike Kowalski for some brief comments before we open the call to your questions.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, gentlemen, for providing everyone with a thorough understanding of Tiffany's performance in 2016. I just want to address a few matters, and then we'll be happy to take your questions. First, we began an external search in early February to fi
componenttext:
Thank you, gentlemen, for providing everyone with a thorough understanding of Tiffany's performance in 2016. I just want to address a few matters, and then we'll be happy to take your questions. 
First, we began an external search in early February to fill the role of Chief Executive Officer when Frederic Cumenal stepped down from that position, and I agreed to become interim CEO. We assumed that it may take time to find the right person with broad experience in brand management with a global perspective and who possesses strong leadership skills to motivate and inspire our Tiffany colleagues around the world. 
Second, although Tiffany and the luxury industry faced numerous macro challenges in 2016, we have not been pleased with our financial performance. While we were able to realize important improvement in gross margin and generate a healthy level of free cash flow, sales results were disappointing, and we were unable to generate sales leverage on our fixed costs. 
Third, and most importantly, we believe that Tiffany has a set of powerful strategies that can propel our business forward in the long term. With the right leadership and pace of execution, we believe there are substantial opportunities to grow our business. Specifically, we are focused on increasing the rate of new product introductions and innovations. And we recently announced the hiring of Reed Krakoff to serve as Chief Artistic Officer. We're also focused on maximizing our marketing effectiveness and building stronger relationships with customers, optimizing our store network and improving our business operations and processes, all while effectively managing our capital and costs. And we remain absolutely committed to our industry-leading effort through our corporate social responsibility and environmental sustainability, an area of great important and relevant to us and, we believe, to our customers as well. In essence, we are committed to executing with excellence the strategies that with -- are within our control and pursuing long-term growth opportunities. 
This May 5, we'll mark the 30th anniversary of Tiffany's initial public offering in 1987. Since then, our company has generally produced strong returns for shareholders. And we intend to pursue opportunities that can continue to generate attractive total shareholder returns in the future. 
In my role as interim CEO, I have been actively engaged with the management teams and employees across our business. And I have no doubt that my colleagues at all levels share an extraordinary sense of dedication and passion for our company. I truly appreciate their efforts. And to all of you on this call, I appreciate your ongoing interest in Tiffany's progress. And now we'd be happy to answer some of your questions.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Omar Saad with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Omar Saad with Evercore ISI.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Warren Cheng on the line for Omar. I just had a question on accelerating the pace of newness. So at the Investor Day last year, you discussed some ways that you're speeding up the process with the use both of product design and also the supply cha
componenttext: This is Warren Cheng on the line for Omar. I just had a question on accelerating the pace of newness. So at the Investor Day last year, you discussed some ways that you're speeding up the process with the use both of product design and also the supply chain and bringing product to market more quickly. What parts of the assortment are turning faster than they were a year ago? And what's changed in terms of your structural capabilities to deliver on frequency and freshness?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly -- this is Mike. Certainly, the portion of the product assortment in which we delivered new -- greater newness at a greater piece is in fashion product. And I think we've seen the sales results to the extent that fashion has grown faster.
componenttext: Well, certainly -- this is Mike. Certainly, the portion of the product assortment in which we delivered new -- greater newness at a greater piece is in fashion product. And I think we've seen the sales results to the extent that fashion has grown faster. So we certainly continue our emphasis on that segment of the assortment. We've also had increased success with sales under the $500 price point. And once again, as we indicated on the call, we've stabilized that segment and we hope to grow it. We have put -- we have begun to put into place many of the innovations that we spoke of earlier to bring product to market. It's still relatively early stages, but we're seeing progress in the speed of bringing product to market and the efficiency with which we do it. And then of course, most importantly, the arrival of Reed several weeks ago, we believe, will be yet another way to increase the pace of newness and new product introduction. So at this point, we're feeling good about 2017 and beyond.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We're also very pleased with the progress we're making on our jewelry research design center and we expect to have that fully online by the end of this fiscal year.
componenttext: We're also very pleased with the progress we're making on our jewelry research design center and we expect to have that fully online by the end of this fiscal year.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We're definitely adding more resources in the whole product development -- design and development area. And you'll see it play out over the course of the next year.
componenttext: We're definitely adding more resources in the whole product development -- design and development area. And you'll see it play out over the course of the next year.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to Lorraine Hutchinson with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: When you talk about increasing the pace of newness, how should we be tracking that? Is it a number of new collections, number of products? And then will Reed's impact to these sales by holiday? Will he be able to get some product in the stores by then?
componenttext: When you talk about increasing the pace of newness, how should we be tracking that? Is it a number of new collections, number of products? And then will Reed's impact to these sales by holiday? Will he be able to get some product in the stores by then?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. Mike again. Certainly, there is a number of individual new products and collections in work. You'll certainly see some of Reed's impact in holiday. Specifically, you'll see luxury collections, accessories, which are very, very exciting. A
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. Mike again. Certainly, there is a number of individual new products and collections in work. You'll certainly see some of Reed's impact in holiday. Specifically, you'll see luxury collections, accessories, which are very, very exciting. And in the non-jewelry collection, you'll see that on or around November. But I think you'll manifest that you'll see the new product -- the pace of new product introduction manifest itself both ways, both in individual new products, important new collections or categories like luxury accessories. You will, of course, see important watch introductions in the second half of the year and, obviously, jewelry collections.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Lorraine, as we've historically said, new jewelry designs in any one year represent less than 10% of our sales on that year. The objective is ultimately to raise that to more than 10%.
componenttext: And Lorraine, as we've historically said, new jewelry designs in any one year represent less than 10% of our sales on that year. The objective is ultimately to raise that to more than 10%.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Oliver Chen with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We'll go next to Oliver Chen with Cowen and Company.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We had a longer-term question in relation to the supply chain. What are your thoughts regarding capacity utilization and how -- and your philosophy regarding vertical integration and the opportunities you see and as it relates to what you've been on a rea
componenttext: We had a longer-term question in relation to the supply chain. What are your thoughts regarding capacity utilization and how -- and your philosophy regarding vertical integration and the opportunities you see and as it relates to what you've been on a really good journey with the net working capital management? And as we -- another topic was IT. I was just curious from a consumer-facing perspective. What features are you looking for to having in terms of what consumers are demanding? And what capabilities will be different in terms of what you're looking for over the next few years?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. I'll try and answer it in the order in which it was presented. So with respect to the supply chain, you're right. We're very pleased with the vertically integrated nature of our supply chain. It does a number of things for us, whi
componenttext: Thanks for the question. I'll try and answer it in the order in which it was presented. So with respect to the supply chain, you're right. We're very pleased with the vertically integrated nature of our supply chain. It does a number of things for us, which is control the quality of the offering, which is to control the pace and the speed of innovation, which we're going to be accelerating and ramping up even further with the jewelry research design center, which will allow us to do fast prototyping and also allow us to get really tight on the design specs, so we can do a lot of design cost element thing work right upfront, which we're very pleased by. We have been looking at ways of for us to maximize the efficiency of the team that we have in all areas. And we've been doing a lot of additional training, which is allowing us to cross use the capacity that we do have within our internal system more efficiently and more effectively each and every year. So we're very pleased with what we're seeing on the supply chain side. With respect to IT, it's an area of clear focus for us. We've been investing a lot behind it. We're confident that we're going to be bringing forward a lot of additional capability that the consumer is going to be the direct beneficiary of. As far as what we're focusing on right now, a lot of it has to do with client telling and a lot of it has to do with our digital capabilities to make the shopping experience more seamless for the customers all around the world.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And the question -- we had -- I had a quick question. Lady Gaga was an exciting kind of aspect to the brand. From a newness perspective, what are you thinking about -- how you're thinking about customers in terms of what you want to target, what's the opp
componenttext: And the question -- we had -- I had a quick question. Lady Gaga was an exciting kind of aspect to the brand. From a newness perspective, what are you thinking about -- how you're thinking about customers in terms of what you want to target, what's the opportunity and thinking about self-purchasing versus gifting as you make -- as you drive a lot of innovation in your portfolio and marketing?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think that it certainly is true that self-purchase and gifting must move forward together. As you know, self-purchase -- greater degrees of self-purchase have always been part of -- has been an objective of this company for many, many years.
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think that it certainly is true that self-purchase and gifting must move forward together. As you know, self-purchase -- greater degrees of self-purchase have always been part of -- has been an objective of this company for many, many years. And I think, to the extent that we're seeing relative strength in our fashion collections and individual fashion items, [indiscernible] that we're making progress and we're going to continue to make that a focus. And at the same time, our investment in luxury collections, luxury accessories and the gifting component of that also is critically important. We think that's terribly important because it's necessary to drive traffic into our stores, so we intend to move forward on all those fronts.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll go next to Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: So the first question I have just with respect to guidance and the initial guidance you put out there for 2017. If I look at those and other figures, particularly the top line numbers, it does assume a better trend that we've seen recently at the chain. I
componenttext: So the first question I have just with respect to guidance and the initial guidance you put out there for 2017. If I look at those and other figures, particularly the top line numbers, it does assume a better trend that we've seen recently at the chain. I know we've talked a lot in the prepared comments and in response to some of the questions about the newness, but how should we think about the drivers of that improved top line? Are there key factors that, that sort of say relies upon? And then the second question is that how -- the cadence of sales through the year. Do you expect better sales later in the year? Or should it be relatively even spread out through the year?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, Brian. It's Mark. We're not talking about the cadence throughout the year, no quarterly guidance, so you'll have to make your own assumptions on that. But clearly, with all of the initiatives that are happening here, in terms of better engaging cust
componenttext: Okay, Brian. It's Mark. We're not talking about the cadence throughout the year, no quarterly guidance, so you'll have to make your own assumptions on that. But clearly, with all of the initiatives that are happening here, in terms of better engaging customers, and here we're talking about product development, and here we're talking about exciting innovations and marketing communication, we have to make some assumptions. And we think, with all of these things happening, we ought to be able to perform a little bit better than we did in 2016.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And let me just add that returning here 5 or so weeks ago, I've been terribly impressed by the number of initiatives. Again, they're in various stages of development. But there's an awful lot going on around here in terms of improving the store experience
componenttext: And let me just add that returning here 5 or so weeks ago, I've been terribly impressed by the number of initiatives. Again, they're in various stages of development. But there's an awful lot going on around here in terms of improving the store experience, the Tiffany Touch customer service program, better goal setting and measurement around the Tiffany experience index, which measures client satisfaction. There's an awful lot happening. And of course, as we've spoken now at some length, the new pace of product introduction. So I think we're reasonably confident that the goals that we've set in terms of sales in 2017 are, in fact, achievable.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: got it. And if I can, could I follow up with one question? With respect to -- you're interested more -- obviously, more focus on the U.S. business, domestic business, but there's a lot of chatter out there within retail about the impact of declining mall
componenttext: got it. And if I can, could I follow up with one question? With respect to -- you're interested more -- obviously, more focus on the U.S. business, domestic business, but there's a lot of chatter out there within retail about the impact of declining mall traffic. I'm recognizing Tiffany's is located in the better malls. But nonetheless, are -- is declining mall traffic at all something that's affecting the Tiffany business?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, one of the reasons that -- of course, it is. We're certainly not immune to that. And as we've said earlier, one of the reasons that we're excited about the luxury accessories collection, the gift collections because it's designed very specifi
componenttext: Yes. I mean, one of the reasons that -- of course, it is. We're certainly not immune to that. And as we've said earlier, one of the reasons that we're excited about the luxury accessories collection, the gift collections because it's designed very specifically to drive traffic into the Tiffany stores. As you know, that's a business that we walked away from slowly, but consistently over the past 10 years. And we think it's time to put that back. So we think that, that can help traffic. And finally, again, improvements in the store experience itself. We're not immune to the declines in store traffic. But we think we have to -- it's up to us to do something about it on an individual store business, whatever may be happening in the mall.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: We're also working proactively to make sure that Tiffany's is relevant and accessible wherever shoppers happen to be. So our cruise ship initiative, as an example, is a way for us to make sure that we are evolving with the current times.
componenttext: We're also working proactively to make sure that Tiffany's is relevant and accessible wherever shoppers happen to be. So our cruise ship initiative, as an example, is a way for us to make sure that we are evolving with the current times.

componenttext: One -- just one quick one for me first, and then I have a follow-up. Did the timing of Chinese New Year help your -- it appeared that your January accelerated from your holiday. Did the timing of Chinese New Year help at all? And would that potentially impact your first quarter?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, the shift did have some -- that refers to January, which happened on the first quarter. But clearly, if we had some benefit in late January, it worked the other way in early February.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, the shift did have some -- that refers to January, which happened on the first quarter. But clearly, if we had some benefit in late January, it worked the other way in early February.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And Mark, I wanted to ask just now that you've been in the seat for a little bit of time and have had a chance to really think deeply about -- you've talked about wanting to help improve efficiency at the business. Could you talk about some o
componenttext: Okay, great. And Mark, I wanted to ask just now that you've been in the seat for a little bit of time and have had a chance to really think deeply about -- you've talked about wanting to help improve efficiency at the business. Could you talk about some of the specific initiatives? I know you talked a bit about this some new order management systems. But anything else as you think about strategies for 2017 and how you can improve the inventory efficiency or optimize the cost structure, that would be helpful.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Certainly. No. Thank you very much for the question. I mean, as with Mike, he made the comment that he was very pleased to see the -- an enormous number of initiatives that were being actioned when he kind of parachuted back in. I will tell you that there
componenttext: Certainly. No. Thank you very much for the question. I mean, as with Mike, he made the comment that he was very pleased to see the -- an enormous number of initiatives that were being actioned when he kind of parachuted back in. I will tell you that there was a lot of things being done in a lot of good regards by a lot of really talented people, which I'm going to now, hopefully, be a partial beneficiary along with all the shareholders that are out there and those of you on the call today. A lot of this is just basic blocking and tackling. We have a global procurement group that's relatively early in its formation, which is doing extremely good work. As we have get our arms around those global spend goals, we're able to negotiate harder and better and with more visibility and with more impact. That's a key initiative. I mentioned earlier the jewelry design center. I don't want to overplay it, but I certainly don't want to undersell it either. Being able to do fast prototyping on the idea that Reed and his team are generating is going to put us well down the path of being able to design for efficiency in all of our internal production processes. And frankly, it will also allow us for those items that we do choose put out to external bid be a lot tighter in that process as well. Clearly, the systems that we have available to us today are going to be optimized in the years ahead. And that's going to allow us to do better assortment planning. And with better assortment planning, we'll be able to do more high-level analytics that go along with that. We'll be able to get pricing in a lot more discrete ways. And we're going to be able to make sure that in each store, we have the right product at the right time or as much as practical versus what we have today. And we have several pretty exciting initiatives all earmarked in that regard. The planned structure, as I indicated earlier, is also doing a lot of really good work to cross-train, so that we have the ability to do multiple operation in multiple sites, and that's allowing us to extract a lot more value. And we're starting to play with some different technologies as well, which, we think, over time, could lead to some additional productivity gains. So there's a broad-based back to the things that we're aggressively pursuing. And I'm confident that we're going to be able to affect our cost structures in a favorable way, which will allow us then to fuel additional monies into other investment areas going forward.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the inventory side, I know there were many years where Tiffany was lengthening out its inventory -- its diamond inventory in order to safeguard against the shortage in supply. And obviously, diamond markets are a little bit different today than back th
componenttext: On the inventory side, I know there were many years where Tiffany was lengthening out its inventory -- its diamond inventory in order to safeguard against the shortage in supply. And obviously, diamond markets are a little bit different today than back then. Is there an opportunity to extract more efficiency out of your diamond inventories by taking a less conservative approach to the need to have inventory on hand?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: The short answer is yes, and that's we're going to be we're actively engaged in as well. Trying to make sure that we're getting the right collection of rough stones and then being able to quickly and efficiently process those is, obviously, an area of foc
componenttext: The short answer is yes, and that's we're going to be we're actively engaged in as well. Trying to make sure that we're getting the right collection of rough stones and then being able to quickly and efficiently process those is, obviously, an area of focus for us.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, that building up of the diamond supply chain was a 10-year process and we're done. We're maxed out. And now there's an opportunity to identify ways to improve it.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, that building up of the diamond supply chain was a 10-year process and we're done. We're maxed out. And now there's an opportunity to identify ways to improve it.

componenttext: I guess, this question that I have is, can you comment a little bit about how January -- the flagship store trended in January and your assumptions into '17 around the flagship store?

componenttextpreview: Bob, it's Mark. I'll just mention that in January, the flagship store technically did very well. But that was really driven by a couple of very large one-off transactions. So we're not going to read too much into that. But technically, that's why you saw
componenttext: Bob, it's Mark. I'll just mention that in January, the flagship store technically did very well. But that was really driven by a couple of very large one-off transactions. So we're not going to read too much into that. But technically, that's why you saw the flagship store down by a considerably smaller amount in the fourth quarter versus what it had been in the holiday period. And we're going to plan somewhat cautiously to the New York flagship store for 2017, but we're not going to share our assumptions with you on that store.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: And obviously, we're going to continue to work with the secret service and the NYPD to maximize access to the store and minimize the disruption. But as you know, it is largely beyond our control, so we'll do what we can. We either have -- we also have, ob
componenttext: And obviously, we're going to continue to work with the secret service and the NYPD to maximize access to the store and minimize the disruption. But as you know, it is largely beyond our control, so we'll do what we can. We either have -- we also have, obviously, other stores here in the city, which we can -- we'll better utilize as the year progresses.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
