headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :  Okay, great. And Mark, I wanted to ask just now that you've been in the seat for a little bit of time and have had a chance to really think deeply about -- you've talked about wanting to help improve efficiency at the business. Could you talk about s
componenttext:
:  
Okay, great. And Mark, I wanted to ask just now that you've been in the seat for a little bit of time and have had a chance to really think deeply about -- you've talked about wanting to help improve efficiency at the business. Could you talk about some of the specific initiatives? I know you talked a bit about this some new order management systems. But anything else as you think about strategies for 2017 and how you can improve the inventory efficiency or optimize the cost structure, that would be helpful.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :  Certainly. No. Thank you very much for the question. I mean, as with Mike, he made the comment that he was very pleased to see the -- an enormous number of initiatives that were being actioned when he kind of parachuted back in. I will tell you that
componenttext:
:  
Certainly. No. Thank you very much for the question. I mean, as with Mike, he made the comment that he was very pleased to see the -- an enormous number of initiatives that were being actioned when he kind of parachuted back in. I will tell you that there was a lot of things being done in a lot of good regards by a lot of really talented people, which I'm going to now, hopefully, be a partial beneficiary along with all the shareholders that are out there and those of you on the call today. A lot of this is just basic blocking and tackling. We have a global procurement group that's relatively early in its formation, which is doing extremely good work. As we have get our arms around those global spend pools, we're able to negotiate harder and better and with more visibility and with more impact. That's a key initiative. I mentioned earlier the jewelry design center. I don't want to overplay it, but I certainly don't want to undersell it either. Being able to do fast prototyping on the idea that Reed and his team are generating is going to put us well down the path of being able to design for efficiency in all of our internal production processes. And frankly, it will also allow us for those items that we do choose put out to external bid be a lot tighter in that process as well. Clearly, the systems that we have available to us today are going to be optimized in the years ahead. And that's going to allow us to do better assortment planning. And with better assortment planning, we'll be able to do more high-level analytics that go along with that. We'll be able to get pricing in a lot more discrete ways. And we're going to be able to make sure that in each store, we have the right product at the right time or as much as practical versus what we have today. And we have several pretty exciting initiatives all earmarked in that regard. The plant structure, as I indicated earlier, is also doing a lot of really good work to cross-train, so that we have the ability to do multiple operation in multiple sites, and that's allowing us to extract a lot more value. And we're starting to play with some different technologies as well, which, we think, over time, could lead to some additional productivity gains. So there's a broad-based basket of things that we're aggressively pursuing. And I'm confident that we're going to be able to affect our cost structures in a favorable way, which will allow us then to fuel additional monies into other investment areas going forward.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

Nice to hear of the progress that you've been making so far on the product side. And it also sounds like there's progress on the gross margin side. If you look at the opportunities going forward, what are you seeing for product input cost and also on the marketing spend? And also, Mike, since you've been back, what's the biggest difference from when you left the operational role?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :  So real quickly on the input side, what I would tell you is that we've been -- in a relatively favorable environment as it relates to both metal prices as well as rough and polished diamonds, we expect that to continue through, at least, the 2017 tim
componenttext:
:  
So real quickly on the input side, what I would tell you is that we've been -- in a relatively favorable environment as it relates to both metal prices as well as rough and polished diamonds, we expect that to continue through, at least, the 2017 time horizon. As you know, we have a relatively long supply chain on rough and polished. So a lot of the cost visibility that we have into '17 is basically pretty tight and borne out by things that have already come to pass, so to speak. And with respect to our metals, we tend to go out with forwards and lock in our metal pricing as well. So we're pretty confident about the gross margin plot that we spoke to in the context of our '17 guidance.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :  And Dana, in terms of what's changed, again, as I said a moment ago, and as Mark indicated when he arrived a few months ago, I think I'm not surprised by it. But I'm certainly impressed by the number of initiatives underway, both to -- in terms of im
componenttext:
:  
And Dana, in terms of what's changed, again, as I said a moment ago, and as Mark indicated when he arrived a few months ago, I think I'm not surprised by it. But I'm certainly impressed by the number of initiatives underway, both to -- in terms of improved customer service, the work that's been doing around inventory productivity and efficiency and IT development. And I think, most importantly, what hasn't changed is that this culture remains very strong and resilient. And everyone at Tiffany, despite the obvious challenges and some of the changes, continues to be passionate about the brand and confident in our future. Tiffany, most certainly, is one of the world's great luxury brand. It's not broken. And everyone here is simply committed more than ever to making it greater. So I feel really good.

I think one would be the pace of innovation. You mentioned some development of additional service metrics in the stores. Again, I think you referenced, I referenced also that Tiffany touch customer service program. I think so much of the effort around -- in addition to obvious new product development and the pace of new product development really is going to be built around enhancing all dimensions of the customer in-store experience.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            I was wondering if you can talk a little bit more about the Asia-Pacific. It seems like you saw jewelry unit growth there in 2016 for the quarter. Also it sounds like Hong Kong may have seen some sequential improvement maybe if you can shar
componenttext:
:  
          I was wondering if you can talk a little bit more about the Asia-Pacific. It seems like you saw jewelry unit growth there in 2016 for the quarter. Also it sounds like Hong Kong may have seen some sequential improvement maybe if you can share your thoughts with that on that region. And also longer term, any updates on how you view the Mainland China opportunity and any learnings from some of the initial foray on how to maybe accelerate some of that growth?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :              Let me start with the last part of your question because it's the easiest. We certainly see the Mainland, if I can use that term, Mainland China opportunity as continuing to be very, very significant. Again, the brand is still in its earl
componenttext:
:    
          Let me start with the last part of your question because it's the easiest. We certainly see the Mainland, if I can use that term, Mainland China opportunity as continuing to be very, very significant. Again, the brand is still in its early -- relatively early stages of development in that market. We have good awareness, but lots of opportunity to improve awareness, lots of opportunity to optimize the store network. So I think we're as optimistic as we've ever been about the opportunities in Greater China.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, and in terms of your question about unit growth, jewelry unit volume growth in Asia-Pacific during the year, part of it was just core better growth but a lot of it was due to the fact that we opened a number of new stores. So that unit
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, and in terms of your question about unit growth, jewelry unit volume growth in Asia-Pacific during the year, part of it was just core better growth but a lot of it was due to the fact that we opened a number of new stores. So that unit growth is not on a comp store basis, it's on a total region basis, total sales basis. But nonetheless, we were pleased with it. And then in terms of Hong Kong, as everyone knows, Hong Kong really softened almost 2.5 years ago, started in October 2014. But finally, in 2016, we started to see some improvement, still down but certainly getting less bad from quarter to quarter. And at what point it will completely bottom out and start growing is anybody's guess, but we certainly think that the worst part is probably behind us and we're getting closer to stabilization there.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            Okay, and my second question, if I could, is in the last year, I think, you mentioned a lot of units under $500, I think maybe up 10% or so. Any sort of material increase in 2017 or 2018 that we should think about for that category, especia
componenttext:
:  
          Okay, and my second question, if I could, is in the last year, I think, you mentioned a lot of units under $500, I think maybe up 10% or so. Any sort of material increase in 2017 or 2018 that we should think about for that category, especially since it seems to be an important area for not only in-store but also online as well?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

componenttext:
:  
          Well, we'll be innovating across all categories in 2017 and 2018. There'll be newness in silver, gold, platinum, diamonds, so we're not going to get too technical in terms of how we're dividing up our newness by category or by material, but there'll certainly be newness in silver just as there will be across every other category.

And then just maybe taking a step back following up on the supply chain commentary, maybe it's still early, but as you look through the operations, you've been referring to the aspects of the integration that you're particularly pleased with? Anything you call out as part of process you might want to or you mentioned the opportunity in changing.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            Two good questions. So, with respect to the loans that we had previously made in order to be able to access supply, the good news is that, that's all largely past us at this point. We have one loan that's outstanding as a performing loan. A
componenttext:
:  
          Two good questions. So, with respect to the loans that we had previously made in order to be able to access supply, the good news is that, that's all largely past us at this point. We have one loan that's outstanding as a performing loan. And after this quarter, it's very de minimis, a couple of million dollars, and as I said, it's a performing loan. That should be all that remains with us. So we think that we have processed through all of that. With respect to your other question, I don't want to evade it because it's a fair question but I think for me, there's just an abundance of opportunities there are [indiscernible]  for us. So a lot of work has been done, a lot of really good work has been done. But that said and despite the fact it's a 180-year-old company, there's still enormous opportunities going forward that we have the ability to access. So maybe one thing I would offer is the state of the IT systems because of the company's rapid growth phase is an opportunity for us now and that we have the ability to stitch that together in a seamless way and that's going to give us a lot of additional capabilities going forward. So maybe one thing is -- I would have thought that maybe there's a little bit more -- an evolved IT infrastructure and research related to the financial cube, but this is something that's easily addressed and we're going to get after in short order, and again, that will become an opportunity.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :  I wanted to just ask a question about the mix of business. It sounds like the silver business is stabilizing and the fashion jewelry business is improving. And I'm wondering if you're encouraged, Mike, that, that mix can continue to be favorable and
componenttext:
:  
I wanted to just ask a question about the mix of business. It sounds like the silver business is stabilizing and the fashion jewelry business is improving. And I'm wondering if you're encouraged, Mike, that, that mix can continue to be favorable and that you're at a turning point in the fashion jewelry business. And for Mark, I was wondering how influential that would be to the gross margin as we look into fiscal '17 and whether or not you think you'd be able to generate the same level of gross margin improvement in '17 as was seen in '16. And just lastly, Mike, or Mark, whoever, on marketing, the legendary marketing campaign launched in the fall, I was wondering if there's any way to discuss the effectiveness of that campaign in reaching the millennial customer, how well that resonated and if the program will move forward.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            Let me try to answer the first question, Janet, around the overall going forward direction of product assortment, product categories. As I think everyone on the call knows, part of the magic of Tiffany over the very, very many years has bee
componenttext:
:  
          Let me try to answer the first question, Janet, around the overall going forward direction of product assortment, product categories. As I think everyone on the call knows, part of the magic of Tiffany over the very, very many years has been our ability to balance that -- those categories and to move forward with them all simultaneously. Critical to that has always been our ability to drive lower-price-point sales because of the very favorable margin profile of that category. And once again, as you've heard before, we've stabilized that segment. We also feel very good about the fashion segment gold -- the fashion part of the segment. And once again, due to the entire mix, that also has -- adds favorable gross margin profile. So I think we're not finished certainly, but right now we're feeling relatively good about the direction of category evolution. And of course, as we've said now many times on the phone, we have the work in progress on watches which we're pleased with and, of course, the upcoming gift collection which also should be additive incremental to gross margin. So on that score, a product balance, relative category growth going forward, we're in a pretty good spot right now.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            And what I would offer is, at the end of the day when you ask questions about gross margin and things, we're really focused on operating margin. We really are trying put together a sustainable business model that lets us eke out about 50 ba
componenttext:
:  
          And what I would offer is, at the end of the day when you ask questions about gross margin and things, we're really focused on operating margin. We really are trying put together a sustainable business model that lets us eke out about 50 basis points on the operating line each and every year. Certainly, within our product offerings, certain groupings within that have higher gross margins than others, silver fashion, as an example. That said, we enjoy pretty attractive gross margins in the absolute across all of our product offerings. And I don't want us to become fixated on gross margin as it relates to product mix because at the end of the day, I'm happy to sell an incremental item across any of our offerings because in the absolute, they're very accretive and attractive to us. So product mix does play into it, but I don't want to overplay the role of that in our overall business model.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            And certainly, we're going to continue to try to drive sales of high jewelry because, again  [indiscernible] are not as robust as they are in other parts of the product spectrum. On the margin, they're just wonderful. So we have no problem
componenttext:
:  
          And certainly, we're going to continue to try to drive sales of high jewelry because, again  [indiscernible] are not as robust as they are in other parts of the product spectrum. On the margin, they're just wonderful. So we have no problem enjoying the success from those sorts of sales. And finally, Janet, the last question about the millennials and the advertising campaign, I don't know. That's always a difficult, unanswerable, difficult-to-know question. But as some quantitative evidence, I would simply point out that, again, the fashion categories, where we've enjoyed the most relative success, so I think that speaks, at least directionally, of some success in improving in appealing to millennials.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            Well, certainly, in terms of timing, they're already at the table. We had our first board meeting, which was a very productive, helpful meeting. Certainly, the new directors, collectively, they bring a wealth of -- obviously, a wealth of hi
componenttext:
:  
          Well, certainly, in terms of timing, they're already at the table. We had our first board meeting, which was a very productive, helpful meeting. Certainly, the new directors, collectively, they bring a wealth of -- obviously, a wealth of highly relevant experience and expertise, whether it's consumer product, luxury and lifestyle products and, obviously, retailing. I don't think that, as we said a couple of weeks ago, we still -- we feel very, very confident in the fundamental strategic direction of the company. So I'm not -- from my perspective, not especially looking for a dramatic, left or right turns in our strategies. I think they, along with the entire board, will help evolve our strategic direction, and again, we're confident that they'll all contribute importantly to that.

componenttext:

But again, I think the key, as I said before, the key to that segment or that distribution channel really is going to be about product innovation and development. So I think I'll leave it at that.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

componenttext:
:

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            So a couple of questions. I guess, one on the product newness factor here. You talked about increasing the pace of newness. Kind of any further color on how you're thinking about that, either from a SKU count perspective or an actual catego
componenttext:
:  
          So a couple of questions. I guess, one on the product newness factor here. You talked about increasing the pace of newness. Kind of any further color on how you're thinking about that, either from a SKU count perspective or an actual category perspective? Because when I look historically about over the last 17 years or at least over the last 10, you guys have done a great job when you announced Tiffany T Collection, the keys collection, the marketing around the Celebration Rings. So when you basically come out with the new category, it does very well. And I'm just trying to get a sense of how you're thinking about launching new collections and versus launching just additional SKUs within existing collections. And then lastly, around SKU count, do you think about increasing gross SKU counts but basically leaving net SKU counts flat to increase SKU count productivity? I'm just trying to get a sense of how you think this all plays out from a product newness perspective.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            Well, let me say the obvious. We're not about to proliferate the SKU count. So probably more or less, your suggestion that, combined with the pace of new product introductions, an increased pace of new product, new collection introductions,
componenttext:
:  
          Well, let me say the obvious. We're not about to proliferate the SKU count. So probably more or less, your suggestion that, combined with the pace of new product introductions, an increased pace of new product, new collection introductions, net SKU count probably will stay where it is. It might even continue to decline a bit. But the key will be building -- growth is going to come from a combination of one new collection. And if you look at the evolution of our assortment over the past 10 years, far more concentrated today in important collections than it was 10 years ago in multiple smaller collections. So we want new collections but they have to be big and they need to be impactful. And of course, Tiffany T is -- would be the model -- one of the models going forward for that. At the same time, we need to be mindful that existing collections Return to Tiffany and Return to Tiffany Love, they have to be renewed and we have to continue to animate and increase and inject energy into those. So it's going to be, as it always is, a very careful balance of making sure that we have significant new collections that marketing can drive at the same time making sure that the core collections that are still the -- that will always be the majority of sales, continue to grow at the same time. So it's a complex balancing act.

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017

Or what has he seen when he's reviewed the business on how you can better tie product launches to the store look and, importantly, the marketing cadence or the marketing look out there with the products on people, et cetera? So how does he -- what's your vision for him? Or what's his vision for the brand and how to tie it all together since he's more -- his role is kind of in charge of multiple areas, not just product?

headline: Tiffany & Co., Q4 2017 Earnings Call, Mar 17, 2017
componenttextpreview: :            I think at this point, I'll decline to speak for Reed. He hasn't been here that long, although he's made, from my perspective, tremendous progress. But I think what you said, if I can just repeat that because I think it's critically importa
componenttext:
:  
          I think at this point, I'll decline to speak for Reed. He hasn't been here that long, although he's made, from my perspective, tremendous progress. But I think what you said, if I can just repeat that because I think it's critically important for everyone on the call, in addition to product design, Reed will lead the brand's artistic and design vision with respect to stores, to e-commerce, to marketing, to advertising, we're right now -- I know, Reed's heavily engaged in looking at that new store prototypes. So I think we're going to look to Reed for, obviously, a comprehensive integrated brand vision. What that brand vision is going to be other than it's not going to be a radical left or right turn from where we are. I think it's going to be a continued evolution and fine-tuning of what we have, but I think it probably would be premature for us to speak about that today.
